title: Life of Hoodoos wayside
listingDescription: Currently the climate here provides a perfect balance of freezing and thawing temperatures to create hoodoos. As global temperatures rise, less frequent freeze/thaw cycles may occur, creating more rounded hoodoos shaped more by rain and chemical weathering than ice.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit explaining how hoodoos form.
images.title: Life of Hoodoos
images.caption: How the hoodoos are formed in four phases.

bodyText:
Rain and melting snow erode the edge of this high plateau at a rate of one to four feet every century. As the rim erodes, harder caprock layers preserve softer rocks below, forming rock walls called fins.

Here at 8,000 feet, nightly temperatures fall below freezing half of the year. Snowmelt and rain trickle into cracks and expand as it turns to ice, fracturing the rock, and forming holes called windows. This process is called "frost wedging."

Chemical weathering also occurs as acids in precipitation dissolve the calcium carbonate that holds the rocks together. As windows expand, the caprock collapses creating irregular rock spires called hoodoos. Bryce Canyon has the greatest concentration of hoodoos on Earth.

Currently the climate here provides a perfect balance of freezing and thawing temperatures to create hoodoos. As global temperatures rise, less frequent freeze/thaw cycles may occur, creating more rounded hoodoos shaped more by rain and chemical weathering than ice.
audioDescription: Sunrise Point overlooks the Bryce Amphitheater, a large bowl-like feature carved into the eastern rim of the plateau by the head waters of Bryce Creek. Ponderosa pine line the rim of the canyon here. To the northeast is Boat Mesa and the Sinking Ship formation set against the stark Pink Cliffs of the Table Cliff Plateau. Below the plateau’s rim, a mass of orange hoodoos and stonewalls are capped with a thick layer of resistant white limestone. Panel title: The Life of Hoodoos Four diagrams across the panel illustrate how hoodoos form. Beginning with the past: a smooth un-weathered high plateau to the present day formation of windows through the rock caused by erosion and freezing and thawing of water. When the connecting arch above the hole or window in the rocks erodes each creates an individual rock spire called a hoodoo. The last diagram demonstrates a completely eroded series of rounded hills, what the hoodoos might look like in the future as weathering processes continue. Captions read: Rain and melting snow erode the edge of this high plateau at a rate of one to four feet every century. As the rim erodes, harder caprock layers preserve softer rocks below, forming rock walls called fins. Then Here at 8,000 feet, nightly temperatures fall below freezing half of the year. Snowmelt and rain trickle into cracks and expand as it turns to ice, fracturing the rock, and forming holes called windows. This process is called "frost wedging." Chemical weathering also occurs as acids in precipitation dissolve the calcium carbonate that holds the rocks together. Next As windows expand, the caprock collapses creating irregular rock spires called hoodoos. Bryce Canyon has the greatest concentration of hoodoos on Earth. Last Once hoodoos are separated, weathering and erosion accelerate, ultimately wearing them down. The rounded hills to the east show where the high plateau rim once existed. At the far edge of the overlook stands one small, lone Limber Pine tree. It clings to the very edge of the eroding cliff, its tangled roots are exposed above ground and curve like legs as if it is standing or walking. A photo of this limber pine is featured on the panel. Caption reads: Exposed roots of trees, like those of the limber pine beside you, illustrate the rate of erosion along the plateau rim. Text continues: Currently the climate here provides a perfect balance of freezing and thawing temperatures to create hoodoos. As global temperatures rise, less frequent freeze/thaw cycles may occur, creating more rounded hoodoos shaped more by rain and chemical weathering than ice.

title: Living off the Land wayside
listingDescription: The Southern Paiutes and other tribes that live in this area know the land, plants, and animals can provide them with everything they need, so they always treat them with respect. Three of the plants they use are highlighted below. Look for them along this path.

images.altText: Three tactile elements are on the panel that feature plants used by the Southern Paiute.
images.title: Living Off the Land
images.caption: Sap and pitch from Ponderosa pine can be used medicinally and for waterproofing..

bodyText: The Southern Paiutes and other tribes that live in this area know the land, plants, and animals can provide them with everything they need, so they always treat them with respect. Three of the plants they use are highlighted below. Look for them along this path.
audioDescription: An illustration recreates how Paiutes lived with their environment. They are shown gathering plants in baskets in the forest near a Wickiup; a small round or cone-shaped house made of natural materials. Three tactile elements are on the panel that feature plants used by the Southern Paiute. Trace your fingers along the stem of a Manzanita. Feel the delicate details of Juniper leaves and their round berries. Touch the scale-like grooves and furrows of Ponderosa Pine bark. Text continues Living Off the Land The Southern Paiutes and other tribes that live in this area know the land, plants, and animals can provide them with everything they need, so they always treat them with respect. Three of the plants they use are highlighted below. Look for them along this path. Manzanita Fruit can be ground up for cooking or used to make cider. Chewed leaves can heal cuts, headaches, and stomach problems. They can also be used as a toothbrush. A photograph of Manzanita shows its delicate pink lanternlike flowers and waxy looking lobe shaped leaves. Rocky Mountain juniper Drinks made from twigs and leaves treat many illnesses. Strips of bark are used for weaving, bedding, and more. Berry-like cones are eaten and used for jewelry. A photograph of a juniper branch shows the flat evergreen leaves and pea sized dark blue berries with a silvery-white waxy bloom, similar to that of a blueberry. Ponderosa pine bark The sweet inner bark is eaten. Sap and pitch are used medicinally and for waterproofing. Wood is used to build shelters and other crafts. Baskets are made from the needles. A close up photograph of Ponderosa pine bark highlights the rusty-orange bark made of overlapping, deeply furrowed scales.

title: Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area
listingDescription: The Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area preserves the natural, historical, and cultural heritage legacies and contributions of Mormon settlement in the West. The heritage area accomplishes this through community-led efforts to connect with the past by telling the Mormon pioneer story.

images.credit: Photo Courtesy of the Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area
images.altText: Two cowboys on horseback silhouetted against sunset.
images.title: Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area
images.caption: Visit the “Old West” - Come to the Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area

bodyText:
Designated by Congress in 2006, this National Heritage Area is managed by the Utah Heritage Highway Alliance. The landscape along Highways 12, 24, and 89, now known as the Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area, was originally occupied by the Paiute, Ute, and San Pitch Native American tribes. Today, the MPNHA spreads across six counties in Utah and stretches from Central Utah to the southern edge of the state. It preserves the story of the first Mormon pioneers in the area who settled there in 1849. The settlers were a “handpicked group of men, women, and children originally hailing from New England, England and Scandinavia,” and traces their settlement patterns across the United States into Utah.

This National Historic Area provides many opportunities to explore Mormon Pioneer heritage with five heritage districts:  

  • Little Denmark – Visit Little Denmark for its rich Scandinavian pioneer influence and stories of immigration. They even have an annual Scandinavian Heritage Festival in Ephraim.  

  • Sevier Valley – A rich landscape where farmers and ranchers followed the ancient Native American tradition of living off the land. Visit the Sevier Valley district for Big Rock Candy Mountain or Lemonade Springs.  

  • Headwaters – This district is known for its rich mining history and network of rivers and tributaries. Visit this area to find “abandoned mines and tales of lost gold.”  

  • Under the Rim – This district is frequented by Hollywood producers looking for a wild west feel. It is named after the red rock rims of the High Plateau of Utah. 

  • Boulder Loop – Visit the Boulder Loop district for an awe-inspiring heritage byway showcasing cowboy and pioneer trails, Bryce Canyon and Capitol Reef National Parks and the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument. 

Each district boasts a unique history while remaining connected to the larger focus of Mormon Pioneer heritage. Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area is beloved among many communities in Utah and is sure to make an impact on all who visit!  

Historic Sites and Points of Interest: 

  • Fairview Museum of History and Art
  • Manti Temple - 1888
  • Casino Star Theatre
  • Moroni Opera House - 1890
  • Big Rock Candy Mountain
  • Scandinavian Heritage Festival
  • Escalante Pioneer Heritage Center
  • Kimberly - Ghost Town Natural History/Pioneer Museum
  • Circleville M. Parker (Butch Cassidy Cabin) - 1878
  • Kanab - Parry Lodge, Home to the Movie Stars Little Hollywood Walk of Fame

Notable People:  

  • Butch Cassidy
  • Brigham Young
  • Chief Sanpitch
  • Chief Blackhawk
  • The Daughters of the Utah Pioneers (past, present, and future
audioDescription: This heritage area landscape is distinguished by its rugged terrain, diverse rock features and geology, and unique small communities connected along Highway 89. There is a variety of geological and geographical features, such as rocky terrain, red cliffs, forests, and rivers.The Colorado River (including its tributaries), wind, and rain have physically shaped this region, which helped to create its canyons, arches, and gullies. Also of interest are Native American sites and cliff drawings, highlighting the years before settlement of Mormon Pioneers.

quickFacts.value: The Mormon Pioneer National Heritage Area (MPNHA) preserves the natural, historical, and cultural heritage legacies and contributions of Mormon settlement in the West. The heritage area accomplishes this through community-led efforts to connect with the past by telling the Mormon pioneer story. By increasing tourism along Utah’s Highways 12, 24, and 89, The MPNHA revitalizes communities through economic development initiatives and drives tourism to small communities along these routes.

title: Mossy Cave
listingDescription: Mossy Cave trail is one of the lowest elevation hikes in the park as well as one of the only hikes that begins with a climb and ends with a descent (most day hikes in the park begin with a descent and end with a climb). It is also the northernmost hike in the park, located just off of SR 12 as it winds its way through the park boundary.

images.altText: A canyon of red rock lined with trees and shrubs contains a waterfall feeding a small stream
images.title: Mossy Cave Trail
images.caption: The Mossy Cave Trail leads to a small waterfall along the way to the alcove (cave)

bodyText:
Mossy Cave is in the northern section of the park, located on Highway 12, approximately 4 miles east of the intersection of Highways 12 and 63. Look for a small parking area on the right-hand side immediately after crossing a little bridge. The Mossy Cave itself is at the end of a short trail. Here too you can see hoodoos and windows without having to hike a steep trail.

At first, this canyon known as Water Canyon, might look like any ordinary Bryce Canyon kind of canyon. It's not. From 1890-1892 mormon pioneers labored with picks and shovels to carve an irrigation ditch from the East Fork of the Sevier River, through the Paunsaugunt Plateau, into this canyon.

Every year since its completion in 1892 (except during the drought of 2002), this canal known as the Tropic Ditch has supplied the communities of Tropic and Cannonville with irrigation water.

Geology

By definition Bryce Canyon is misnamed, it is not a real "canyon". Canyons are carved by flowing water. Most of the "canyons" of Bryce are carved by ice forming in cracks - a process known as frost wedging. Even though the Tropic Ditch has been flowing for only a century it has changed the geology of Water Canyon. As you hike up the Mossy Cave Trail, notice how the higher elevations of this "canyon" have the lumpy, broken, and random texture typical of Bryce Canyon and its hoodoos. You will also see how the lower section is without hoodoos, and has smooth angled sides looking like a 'V' in cross-section. Because of this little water course, it is unlikely that hoodoos will form here. The existing ones will eventually crumble and Water Canyon will have completed its metamorphosis into a "real canyon."

Nature

The presence of water alone is what makes Water Canyon unique. Although you might not see them (animals tend to avoid busy trails - especially in daylight hours), a wide diversity of animals come here regularly to quench their thirst. The supply of water is still recent enough that nature hasn't quite caught up yet. Eventually more riparian trees like willows and cottonwoods will probably grow here. In the meantime you'll be surprised to see some plants that you might expect to find along a brook in a mountain meadow, such as Mountain Death Camas and Watson Bog Orchid.

Trails

Visit the Mossy Cave Trail page for more information.
audioDescription: A panel titled Mossy Cave Trail displays a map of the trail to mossy cave and waterfall. A “you are here” marker shows our location at the trailhead parking lot right off Hwy 12. Two bridges cross over Tropic Ditch along the trail. The trail forks near the end, access to the waterfall to the right and mossy cave to the left. There are two wayside exhibits along the trail, one just after the first bridge and one at Mossy Cave. Map Caption reads: This 0.4 mile trail to mossy cave is a gradual ascent with some short, steep sections. Pace yourself; Allow for the thinner air at this elevation. Caution Avoid damage to fragile cave formations. A photograph below the map shows a small waterfall flowing into a narrow muddy stream: tropic ditch. Text reads: Follow the stream bank to the fork in the trail the left path leads to mossy cave, where ice draperies often last until summer and delicate Moss grows year-round. The right-hand spur reaches a low waterfall dramatic after a storm or spring snowmelt. Along the trail there are views of Bryce Canyon hoodoos, eroded red pinnacles period look for “windows” weather through the thin rock walls.

title: Mossy Cave Hike the Hoodoos wayside
listingDescription: Hike the Hoodoos Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

images.altText: A wayside panel with a waterfall describes the hike the hoodoos program and how to obtain a reward
images.title: Mossy Cave Hiked the Hoodoos
images.caption: Mossy Cave Hike the Hoodoos wayside (be sure to include yourself in your photo!)

bodyText:
I Hiked the Hoodoos

Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

1. Hike a minimum of 3 mi / 4.8 km, or find at least 3 benchmarks and complete steps 2 through 4 below.

2. Each individual must have either a pencil rubbing of the benchmark (see Jr. Ranger Book) or a"selfie"with the benchmark.

3. Only special "I Hiked the Hoodoos" benchmarks qualify for the reward.

4. Rewards are available at the Visitor Center!

See your park newspaper or Junior Ranger book for more information. Benchmarks are located on Mossy Cave, Rim Trail, Tower Bridge, Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, Peekaboo Loop, Sheep Creek, and the Bristlecone Loop trails.

Text continues: You have found the mossy cave benchmark (the metal disk below) on the I hiked the hoodoos challenge a way to stay healthy and have fun in your National Park to meet the challenge either find 3 benchmarks or hike 3 miles on trails that have benchmarks bring rubbings of the benchmarks or photos of yourself with them to the visitor center to receive a small reward. A metal disk is mounted to the panel. Words have been etched into the metal: Bryce Canyon National Park mossy cave I hiked the hoodoos elevation 6941 feet above sea level. Below the benchmark medallion text reads: This project was made possible in part by a grant from the National Park foundation through the generous support of the Coca Cola foundation. Two photographs along the right side of the panel show the two types of water features found along the trail; a waterfall and a natural spring. Text reads: The trail splits here with each side leading to water that is crucial for life in a dry land. To the left, a natural spring seeps from a rocky Cliff, watering plants as it has for untold time. To the right, water Canyon is fed by the tropic ditch an irrigation canal dug by Mormon pioneers in the late 1800s. Historically, this washed flowed only during periods of melting snow or heavy rain today, irrigation water flows May to October, bringing life to Valley crops and orchards.

bodyText:
Two upright panels are here near the parking lot; the first is the orientation to Bryce Canyon with full park map. The second provides details about our location here at Mossy Cave.

Bryce Canyon Orientation Wayside
Since no river runs through it, Bryce Canyon is not truly a canyon. Instead, it is a series of natural amphitheaters carved into the edge of the Paunsaugunt Plateau. These bowl-shaped features contain the world's largest collection of varied rock spires known as hoodoos. We welcome you to Bryce Canyon National Park and invite you to discover the sublime beauty and rich history of this land.

Photographs alongside the map highlight four areas of the park:
The first, a view along the trail as it approaches Mossy Cave, a sheltered overhang of rock. Caption reads: Take a streamside walk to a water fall and shady grotto. Then a man with a child in a backpack descends the trail through the Queen's Garden, orange rock spires and formations described as sculptures. Caption reads: Enjoy a moderately difficult descent into the Bryce Amphitheater. Bryce Amphitheater at Sunrise Point.

Next Bryce Amphitheater, the forested edge of the plateau in the distance gives way to a bowl shaped feature below us filled with red and white spires of rock coming up from the bottom like jagged teeth. Caption Reads: Find this iconic area along the first three miles of the park road.

Last, Natural Bridge, a natural arch or window of rock, through which can be seen the trees that grow in the canyon below. Caption reads: Visit one of many beautiful views along the 18-mile scenic drive to Rainbow Point.

Mossy Cave Orientation Wayside
This streamside walk leads to a spring-formed alcove that fills with summer moss and winter ice. At one time, water only flowed through Water Canyon after summer storms and spring snowmelt. After settlers completed an irrigation canal in 1892, water was diverted from the plateau above, steeply eroding these fragile canyon walls and feeding a waterfall that regularly freezes in winter.

Help us protect this delicate area by always staying on designated trails.

Know Before You Go
● Stay on the designated trail.
● Watch for seasonally fast-moving water.
● This is challenging environment for plants. Stay on the trail and leave them for all to enjoy.
audioDescription: Two upright panels are here near the parking lot; the first is the orientation to Bryce Canyon with full park map. The second provides details about our location here at Mossy Cave. A “you are here” marker shows our location at the trailhead parking lot right off Hwy 12. This panel displays a map of the trail to Mossy Cave and waterfall. Trail Length: 0.8-mile (1.3 km) roundtrip. Difficulty: Easy. Two bridges cross over Tropic Ditch along the trail. The trail forks near the end, to the right access to the waterfall and to the left Mossy Cave. Two photographs to the left of the map show a family of hikers approaching Mossy Cave and a small waterfall flowing into a narrow muddy stream known as Tropic Ditch. Captions read: Look for the waterfall along Mossy Cave Trail. Follow the short trail to a small, shaded cave. Along the trail there are four wayside exhibits that describe the Pinyon/Juniper Life zone, how water was brought to the desert and how Mossy Cave was formed, along with three botanical markers that highlight the Pinyon pine, Utah Juniper and the Gambel Oak trees, A “Hike the Hoodoos” medallion can be found just after the first bridge. A photograph on the bottom half of the panel shows a woman with a child in a backpack on her back, she is holding the hand of another child as they walk toward a bridge along the trail to Mossy Cave Trees and shrubs line the trail where there are views of eroded red pinnacles of rock known as Bryce Canyon hoodoos. Caption reads: All ages enjoy the easy hike at mossy cave. Text continues Mossy Cave This streamside walk leads to a spring-formed alcove that fills with summer moss and winter ice. At one time, water only flowed through Water Canyon after summer storms and spring snowmelt. After settlers completed an irrigation canal in 1892, water was diverted from the plateau above, steeply eroding these fragile canyon walls and feeding a waterfall that regularly freezes in winter. Help us protect this delicate area by always staying on designated trails. Know Before You Go ● Stay on the designated trail. ● Watch for seasonally fast-moving water. ● This is challenging environment for plants. Stay on the trail and leave them for all to enjoy. An image of a bronze colored, coin-like medallion is displayed. Caption reads: One “Hike the Hoodoos” medallion is found along this trail. Find it, then take a photo or rubbing. When you’ve found three different medallions or hiked 3 miles (4.8 km) on trails that have benchmarks (see Visitor Guide) take them to the visitor center for a reward. A color photograph shows hikers walking along the switch backs on the Navajo Loop trail near Sunset Point. Massive, curving, jagged orange and red rock spires surround them. A detailed map of the park runs along the right side of the panel and illustrates overlooks, shuttle stops, picnic areas, and camping and hiking opportunities. Panel content describes backcountry rules, safety, trails and campsites in the vicinity. Further Information about visiting the park, safety and rules can be found in the Safety section of the app. Text reads: Bryce Canyon Since no river runs through it, Bryce Canyon is not truly a canyon. Instead, it is a series of natural amphitheaters carved into the edge of the Paunsaugunt Plateau. These bowl-shaped features contain the world's largest collection of varied rock spires known as hoodoos. We welcome you to Bryce Canyon National Park and invite you to discover the sublime beauty and rich history of this land. Photographs alongside the map highlight four areas of the park: The first, a view along the trail as it approaches Mossy Cave, a sheltered overhang of rock. Caption reads: Take a streamside walk to a water fall and shady grotto. Then a man with a child in a backpack descends the trail through the Queen's Garden, orange rock spires and formations described as sculptures. Caption reads: Enjoy a moderately difficult descent into the Bryce Amphitheater. Bryce Amphitheater at Sunrise Point. Next Bryce Amphitheater, the forested edge of the plateau in the distance gives way to a bowl shaped feature below us filled with red and white spires of rock coming up from the bottom like jagged teeth. Caption Reads: Find this iconic area along the first three miles of the park road. Last, Natural Bridge, a natural arch or window of rock, through which can be seen the trees that grow in the canyon below. Caption reads: Visit one of many beautiful views along the 18-mile scenic drive to Rainbow Point. 002 Pinyon /Juniper Life Zone The first exhibit before the bridge along the trail to Mossy Cave highlights the Pinyon /Juniper Life Zone A relief map of the park marks our location at 6000 ft elevation where this Pinyon /Juniper life zone is possible. The map also marks the next two life zones that occur at higher elevations: Ponderosa Pine life zone at 8000ft and then the Mixed Conifer life zone at 8,500ft. A background photograph shows a cluster of shrubs and trees you may find along the trail that illustrate the diversity of species found here: Juniper, Ponderosa pine, Greenleaf manzanita, gambel oak and Pinyon Pine with its buff colored cones and the spikey narrowleaf yucca. Animals are featured that include a Uinta chipmunk, Greater short-horned lizard and a Pinyon Jay with a special note not to feed the animals. Text continues: Bryce Canyon’s elevation ranges 2,500 feet (762 m) from Rainbow Point to the canyon bottoms, creating a wide range of temperatures and precipitation resulting in three climatic or life zones—Pinyon/Juniper, Ponderosa Pine, Mixed Conifer. More than a thousand plant species inhabit the park, while dozens of animals, including over 100 species of birds, move throughout these zones. The Mossy Cave Trail winds through a through a forest community defined by pinyon pine and juniper. Look for short evergreen trees and a variety of desert and upland shrubs. Springs and irrigation water found here also create refuges for more water-dependent plants.

title: Mossy Cave wayside
listingDescription: At Mossy Cave, slightly acidic groundwater seeps through the harder limestone layer, dissolving and eroding the softer layers underneath. This cool, moist, shaded environment is a perfect habitat for mosses to thrive. As temperatures drop, the dripping water freezes, creating impressive icicles that sometimes last into summer. Please do not enter the cave and help us protect this fragile environment.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit describing how Mossy Cave formed.
images.title: Mossy Cave wayside
images.caption: The Mossy Cave wayside exhibit.

bodyText: At Mossy Cave, slightly acidic groundwater seeps through the harder limestone layer, dissolving and eroding the softer layers underneath. This cool, moist, shaded environment is a perfect habitat for mosses to thrive. As temperatures drop, the dripping water freezes, creating impressive icicles that sometimes last into summer. Please do not enter the cave and help us protect this fragile environment.
audioDescription: A hike up a narrow path along a ledge ends at Mossy Cave. The panel features a photograph of a wintertime display of ice buildup in the form of icicles under this rocky overhang that creates a shaded, cave like alcove. Three diagrams show the geologic process of the formation of Mossy Cave. The first gives an idea of what this landscape might have looked like before any erosion began; a layered reddish rock of silt, mud and softer limestones is capped with a hard and porous limestone layer. The next diagram shows acidic groundwater seeping down through the surface porous layers to erode the softer layers beneath. Over time this process of erosion and freezing and thawing brings us to the last diagram which shows the current appearance of this formation at Mossy Cave: a cave-like eroded alcove or grotto, protected by a rocky overhang. Text Continues At Mossy Cave, slightly acidic groundwater seeps through the harder limestone layer, dissolving and eroding the softer layers underneath. This cool, moist, shaded environment is a perfect habitat for mosses to thrive. As temperatures drop, the dripping water freezes, creating impressive icicles that sometimes last into summer. Please do not enter the cave and help us protect this fragile environment.

title: Natural Bridge
listingDescription: Like some other features in the park, Natural Bridge is not what its name would suggest. Natural bridges are formed by the movement of a stream or river cutting through rock. The impressive feature seen here is instead a natural arch, or window, formed primarily by the expansion of ice in cracks deep within.

images.altText: A glowing orange rock arch stands among limestone slopes above a forested landscape
images.title: Natural Bridge
images.caption: Natural Bridge is one of the most iconic overlooks along the Southern Scenic Drive

bodyText:
Like some other features in the park, Natural Bridge is not what its name would suggest. Natural bridges are formed by the movement of a stream or river cutting through rock. The impressive feature seen here is instead a natural arch, or window, formed primarily by the expansion of ice in cracks deep within. A more weathering-resistant layer of rock protects the softer rocks below from more rapid erosion, while ice, rain, and wind slowly open the arch wider and wider.
As the edge of the plateau has eroded back, a small gully has formed that flows with rain and melting snow (now more than 125 feet below the arch). Undoubtedly some day the top of the arch will collapse, leaving behind new hoodoos on either side.

Trails

No trails depart from this area.

Landscape Features

To the North

View the eroded and forested edge of the Paunsagunt Plateau, carved by rain and melting snow into bowl-shaped amphitheaters.

To the East

Here the iron-oxide colored limey mudstones of the Pink Cliffs of Bryce Canyon are being weathered and eroded by rain and melting snow to form a bowl-shaped amphitheater separated from amphitheaters to the north and south. Within this amphitheater, Natural Bridge is being formed by the same process as all hoodoos: walls or fins are formed by the presence of harder, more erosion resistant cap layers as the plateau rim erodes backwards through the action of rain and melting snow. Windows then form as rain and melting snow trickle into cracks within these fins. Overnight freezing temperatures cause this water to expand as it turns to ice, breaking the rock apart from within and creating windows--of which Natural Bridge is a very large example. Eventually, the caprock will collapse, leaving behind rock spires on either side of the window known as "hoodoos".

To the West

The rolling ponderosa forest of the Paunsaugunt plateau is deeply incised here by water travelling north to the Tropic Reservoir. The direction of flow is decided by the plateau's upward tilt to the south and has created a rain divide between the Great Basin of Nevada and the Colorado River that follows the edge of this plateau.

To the South

View the eroded and forested edge of the Paunsagunt Plateau, carved by rain and melting snow into bowl-shaped amphitheaters.
audioDescription:
A sign at this overlook reads Natural Bridge elevation 8627 ft.
Natural Bridge, one of several arches in Bryce Canyon, is a brilliant reddish orange formation that spans more than 125 feet above a washout gully. The narrow gully descends steeply down from the rim of the plateau through the tight, horseshoe shaped arch. The reddish stone arch acts as a window, framing the deep green of the Ponderosa Pine forest in the canyon below. A Wayside at the overlook describes how these arches are formed.

title: Natural Bridge wayside
listingDescription: This "bridge" is technically an arch. Natural bridges are carved by rushing streams, but here, subtler forces of frost-wedging, chemical weathering, and gravity are at work. Today, the arch spans 85 feet (26 m) and appears solid and enduring, but weather is constantly chipping away at the opening. It may last hundreds or thousands of years, or it could collapse tomorrow.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit explaining how arches are formed.
images.title: Natural Bridge wayside
images.caption: This "bridge" is technically an arch created by forces of frost-wedging and chemical weathering.

bodyText: This "bridge" is technically an arch. Natural bridges are carved by rushing streams, but here, subtler forces of frost-wedging, chemical weathering, and gravity are at work. Today, the arch spans 85 feet (26 m) and appears solid and enduring, but weather is constantly chipping away at the opening. It may last hundreds or thousands of years, or it could collapse tomorrow.
audioDescription: Here at the Natural Bridge viewing area a panel explains through a progression diagram how arches are formed. Natural Bridge, one of several arches in Bryce Canyon, is a brilliant reddish orange formation that spans more than 125 feet above a washout gully. The narrow gully descends steeply down from the rim of the plateau through the tight, horseshoe shaped arch. The reddish stone arch acts as a window, framing the deep green of the Ponderosa pine forest in the canyon below. A series of four diagrams on the panel show how a natural bridge, or arch, was created, and what it may look like in the future if the same processes continue. Text Reads: Natural Bridge This "bridge" is technically an arch. Natural bridges are carved by rushing streams, but here, subtler forces of frost-wedging, chemical weathering, and gravity are at work. Today, the arch spans 85 feet (26 m) and appears solid and enduring, but weather is constantly chipping away at the opening. It may last hundreds or thousands of years, or it could collapse tomorrow. The first illustration shows a narrow strip of rock wall or “fin” jutting out from the edge of the plateau. Caption Reads: The forces of freezing and thawing water (frost-wedging), combined with gravity, and slightly-acidic rain (chemical weathering) eroded the rock from within and without. The next illustration shows a small arched hole opening forming at the base of the rock wall. Caption Reads: Hollows may have developed on both sides of the wall, gradually deepening, until they eroded through. The gully below did not form the arch, but it did deepen the opening. The third illustration shows the arch widening and spanning higher up near the top of the wall, creating a bridge like appearance. Caption Reads: The rich coloring of the arch’s limestone comes from iron oxides deposited millions of years ago. The grey caprock above— a harder dolomitic limestone—erodes more slowly than the softer rocks beneath. The final illustration shows the eventual collapse of the Natural Bridge archway, the top of the arch has collapsed into the canyon, only the two hoodoo pillars on either side of the span remain standing. Caption Reads: The harder caprock will one day succumb to gravity and fall. The park will have one less arch, but a new, towering hoodoo will take its place.

title: Nature's Symphony wayside
listingDescription: Close your eyes and listen. What do you hear? Soundscapes, the combined sounds from natural and non-natural sources, are an important resource in national parks. Non-natural sounds, such as those from vehicles, aircraft, and other visitors, can disturb nature's delicate balance and visitor experiences. Soundscape monitoring helps us understand the impact of human-caused noises on the natural world.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit explaining how Bryce Canyon maintains natural soundscapes.
images.title: Nature's Symphony wayside
images.caption: You can help preserve this soundscape by being mindful of the sounds you make.

bodyText:
Close your eyes and listen. What do you hear? Soundscapes, the combined sounds from natural and non-natural sources, are an important resource in national parks. Non-natural sounds, such as those from vehicles, aircraft, and other visitors, can disturb nature's delicate balance and visitor experiences. Soundscape monitoring helps us understand the impact of human-caused noises on the natural world.

Animals depend on natural sounds to communicate, find mates and food, avoid danger, establish territory, and more. You can help preserve this soundscape by being mindful of the sounds you make, and listening to the world around you. You may hear the winds of spring, the thunderstorms of summer, or even the snap and crackle of ice shaping the landscape in colder months.
audioDescription: Here at Paria View is a quieter view of towering limestone cliffs and the broader Paria valley beyond. One prominent castle-like hoodoo rises high above a steep and relatively narrow amphitheater more than 500 ft deep. Down and to the southeast is the Yellow Creek and Paria River watershed. Yellow Creek begins in the Paria Amphitheater and joins the Paria River further on where it carves down through the Grey and White Cliffs of the Grand Staircase in the distance. A panel here explains how this area offers one of the best locations for natural soundscapes. A photograph emphasizes a person standing alone, his back is to us as he looks out upon the landscape. Text reads: Nature’s Symphony Close your eyes and listen. What do you hear? Soundscapes, the combined sounds from natural and non-natural sources, are an important resource in national parks. Non-natural sounds, such as those from vehicles, aircraft, and other visitors, can disturb nature's delicate balance and visitor experiences. Soundscape monitoring helps us understand the impact of human-caused noises on the natural world. A map of the United States titled “mapping sound” shows high noise pollution levels in the lower 48 states as glowing yellow hot spots of color and low noise pollution levels as dark blue. The greatest areas of noise pollution are west of the Mississippi River and in major metropolitan areas. Our location here at Bryce Canyon is one of the darkest blue areas on the map. Darker blue areas show extremely low levels of noise pollution. Text continues: Animals depend on natural sounds to communicate, find mates and food, avoid danger, establish territory, and more. You can help preserve this soundscape by being mindful of the sounds you make, and listening to the world around you. You may hear the winds of spring, the thunderstorms of summer, or even the snap and crackle of ice shaping the landscape in colder months.

title: Navajo Loop Hike the Hoodoos
listingDescription: Hike the Hoodoos Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

images.altText: A wayside showing a tall red rock spire describes hoodoos and the Hike the Hoodoos program
images.title: Navajo Loop Hike the Hoodoos wayside
images.caption: Navajo Loop Hike the Hoodoos wayside (be sure to include yourself in your photo!)

bodyText:
I Hiked the Hoodoos

Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

1. Hike a minimum of 3 mi / 4.8 km, or find at least 3 benchmarks and complete steps 2 through 4 below.

2. Each individual must have either a pencil rubbing of the benchmark (see Jr. Ranger Book) or a"selfie"with the benchmark.

3. Only special "I Hiked the Hoodoos" benchmarks qualify for the reward.

4. Rewards are available at the Visitor Center!

See your park newspaper or Junior Ranger book for more information. Benchmarks are located on Mossy Cave, Rim Trail, Tower Bridge, Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, Peekaboo Loop, Sheep Creek, and the Bristlecone Loop trails.
audioDescription: Navajo Loop Hike the Hoodoos wayside 348 words This exhibit panel is at the bottom of Navajo Loop where it joins with the Queen's Garden Trail and Peekaboo Loop. The panel is placed in a flat area of natural sediment, beside wooden benches that face east southeast, beneath juniper and ponderosa pines, deep within the hoodoo-filled Bryce Amphitheater. An exhibit panel titled: Hike the Hoodoos, Navajo Loop, promotes the parks Hike the Hoodoos challenge. There are nine "Hike the Hoodoos" benchmarks located along eight different hiking trails in the park. Each exhibit has a large round coin-like metal, medallion called a benchmark inserted into the panel. The right side of the panel illustrates a natural feature found at the location. Here a photograph of hoodoo spires covered in snow. Text reads: Water and ice are the sculptors of Bryce canyon's Wonderland melting snow and torrential rain erode the softer stone and carry it downhill leaving behind massive slabs of standing rock. Ice cracks this rock apart as it freezes and thaws weathering it into fins and hoodoos that spark curiosity and imagination. The left side of each panel provides a trail map with current location, the benchmark and a description of the hoodoo challenge: This map shows our location to the east of Sunset Point on the Navajo Loop trail. Text reads: You have found the Navajo Loop benchmark (metal disk below) on the “I hiked the hoodoos” challenge -- a way to stay healthy and have fun in your National Park. To meet the challenge: either find 3 benchmarks, or hike 3 miles on trails that have benchmarks see map and park newspaper or junior Ranger booklet bring rubbings of the benchmarks or photos of yourself with them to the visitor center to receive a small reward. The coin-shaped metal benchmark is mounted to the panel. Words have been etched into the metal: Bryce Canyon National Park Navajo Loop I hiked the hoodoos elevation 7457 feet above sea level. Text continues: This project was made possible in part by a grant from the National Park foundation through the generous support of the Coca Cola foundation.

title: Navajo Loop Trailhead
listingDescription: The iconic Navajo Loop Trail begins and ends at Sunset Point, travelling by switchbacks down between narrow walls of colorful limestone with views of towering Douglas-fir trees and the park's most famous hoodoo: Thor's hammer. The loop has two sides, the Two Bridges side and the Wall Street side. The Two Bridges side is open year-round, however the Wall Street side is closed in months when precipitation combines with freezing overnight temperatures.

images.altText: Switchbacks descend along a redrock trail between tall walls of rock and trees
images.title: Two Bridges side of Navajo Loop
images.caption: The Two Bridges side of the Navajo Loop descends into the Bryce Amphitheater

bodyText:
Navajo Loop

Difficulty: Moderate
Total Distance: 1.3 miles (2.2 km)
Elevation change: 550 feet (168 m)
Average time: 1-2 hours

The iconic Navajo Loop Trail begins and ends at Sunset Point, travelling by switchbacks down between narrow walls of colorful limestone with views of towering Douglas-fir trees and the park's most famous hoodoo: Thor's hammer. The loop has two sides, the Two Bridges side and the Wall Street side.
The Two Bridges side is open year-round, however the Wall Street side is closed in months when precipitation combines with freezing overnight temperatures. 
More about the trail

Combination Loops

This trail can be combined with the Queen's Garden to form the 2.9 mile (4.6 km) Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop and the Peekaboo Loop to form the 6.4 mile (10.2 km) Figure-8 Combination Loop.

Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop

Difficulty: Moderate
Total Distance: 2.9 miles (4.6 km)
Elevation change: 600 feet (138 m)
Average time: 2-3 hours

Perhaps the park's most popular and iconic trail, the Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop can begin at either Sunrise or Sunset Point but is recommended in a clockwise direction; this is done by descending on the Queen's Garden Trail and ascending the Navajo Loop Trail (Two Bridges side recommended for year-round use and iconic views of Thor's Hammer; Wall Street side is only open in summer). Whether one begins at Sunset or Sunrise Point, these two viewpoints are connected by a flat, 0.5 mile (0.8 km) section of the Rim Trail that completes the loop. If one begins at Sunset Point, they should begin by hiking this section of the Rim Trail to Sunrise Point.
More about the trail

Navajo / Peekaboo Combination Loop

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 4.9 miles (7.8 km)
Elevation change: 1581 feet (482 m)
Average time: 3-4 hours

Like the Figure-8 Combination below, this hike combines two loops into one longer hike. This combination begins at Sunset Point with a descent of the Navajo Loop trail. It is recommended to descend along the Wall Street side of the loop (Wall Street side closes in winter, in which case one should use the Two Bridges side to descend and return). After reaching the bottom of the Navajo Loop a short connecting trail leads from here across Bryce Creek to the Peekaboo Loop Trail. Keeping left will take hikers in a clockwise direction around the strenuous Peekaboo Loop and return them to the intersection of Navajo and Queen's Garden Trails. From here hikers ascend back up to Sunset Point (Two Bridges side recommended for year-round use).

Figure-8 Combination Loop

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 6.4 miles (10.2 km)
Elevation change: 320 feet (98 m)
Average time: 4-5 hours

The Figure-8 Combination combines the Peekaboo Loop Trail with the Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop to create a 6.4 mile (10.2 km) combination of two loops. Like the Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop, the Peekaboo Loop should be hiked in a clockwise direction. One can begin at either Sunset or Sunrise Point. From Sunset Point, one would begin by first hiking the 0.5 mile (0.8 km) section of the Rim Trail that leads north to Sunrise Point, then descend the Queen's Garden Trail to its intersection with the Navajo Loop. A short connecting trail leads from here across Bryce Creek to the Peekaboo Loop Trail. Keeping left will take hikers in a clockwise direction around the strenuous Peekaboo Loop and return them to the intersection of Navajo and Queen's Garden Trails. From here hikers ascend back up to Sunset Point (Two Bridges side recommended for year-round use; Wall Street only open in summer).

I Hiked the Hoodoos

Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

1. Hike a minimum of 3 mi / 4.8 km, or find at least 3 benchmarks and complete steps 2 through 4 below.

2. Each individual must have either a pencil rubbing of the benchmark (see Jr. Ranger Book) or a"selfie"with the benchmark.

3. Only special "I Hiked the Hoodoos" benchmarks qualify for the reward.

4. Rewards are available at the Visitor Center!

See your park newspaper or Junior Ranger book for more information. Benchmarks are located on Mossy Cave, Rim Trail, Tower Bridge, Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, Peekaboo Loop, Sheep Creek, and the Bristlecone Loop trails.

The platform of Sunset Point is adjacent to the east, and the Rim Trail travels north and south from here.

bodyText:
This popular trail has two sides, one descending into the narrow paths of Wall Street and the other to the erosion-resistant Two Bridges and Thor's Hammer. Hikers can also connect to the Peekaboo Loop and Queen's Garden Trail to create larger loops. See the Visitor Guide for information on combination loops.

A sign at the top of this panel will state whether the Wall Street paths are either closed or open. Rockfalls and seasonal conditions sometimes necessitate closures. If the Wall Street area is closed, this trail is not a loop.
audioDescription: Here at Sunset Point is the Trailhead to the Navajo Loop trail. A map illustrates that we are at Sunset Point overlook. A graphic provides details about the trail: Length: 1.4 mile (2.3 km) Difficulty: Moderate Total Ascent: 515 feet (157 m) A photograph along the bottom of the panel is a view looking up as people hike above us on the switch backs of the Navajo Loop trail. An inset photograph shows a park worker investigating a rockfall with a caption that reads: Rockfall is always possible at Bryce but is most likely during rainstorms and winter months. A bronze coin-shaped medallion on the panel signals that One “Hike the Hoodoos” medallion is found along this trail. Find it, then take a photo or rubbing. When you’ve found three different medallions or hiked 3 miles (4.8 km) on trails that have benchmarks (see Visitor Guide) take them to the visitor center for a reward. Hikers can also connect to the Peekaboo Loop and Queen's Garden Trail to create larger loops. See the Visitor Guide for information on combination loops. A sign at the top of this panel will state whether the Wall Street paths are either closed or open. Rockfalls and seasonal conditions sometimes necessitate closures. If the Wall Street area is closed, this trail is not a loop.

The North Campground Outdoor Theater provides a venue for outdoor ranger programming, typically evening programs. Since it is outdoors, programs are only offered here during peak season / warmer months.
Check out the park's calendar page for all ranger programming.
audioDescription: North Campground Outdoor Theater 89 words To the east of the North Campground along a wide crushed stone path that winds uphill is the North Campground Outdoor Theater with tiers of seating in an open sloped area for programs and events. Two sections of seating are separated by an aisle and face a narrow, roofed stage made of logs also painted dark brown. On both sides of the aisle sit 15 rows of long, brown metal framed benches with wood slat seats. The area is surrounded and shaded by ponderosa pine trees. A program schedule is available at the Visitor Center.

title: Orientation Panel waysides
listingDescription: At the entrance to the visitor center are five upright orientation panels along a curved stone wall. The panels provide photographs, maps, text and a chart of information on park amenities, exploring Bryce canyon, the hiking trails, the Bryce Amphitheater, and Junior Ranger activities.

images.altText: Five informational signs stand side by side behind a curved stone wall.
images.title: Orientation Panels
images.caption: "Park Orientation" waysides

bodyText:
At the entrance to the visitor center are five upright orientation panels along a curved stone wall. The panels provide photographs, maps, text and a chart of information on park amenities, exploring Bryce canyon, the hiking trails, the Bryce Amphitheater, and Junior Ranger activities.

From left to right,

The first panel: Park amenities
Where to eat, stay and play. 
Lodging, campgrounds, museum & movie, shuttle bus, trail rides, food services & supplies.

The second panel: Explore Bryce Canyon
Five great things to experience in Bryce Canyon National Park: sunrise, sunset, star gazing, Ranger programs. Top 6 hikes: Queens garden, Mossy cave, Rim trail, Bristlecone loop trail, Peekaboo loop and Fairyland loop. 

The third panel: Hiking Trails and the Bryce Amphitheater
This panel breaks up the hiking experience into 15 trails within 3 categories: easy, moderate and strenuous, provides the trail name, round trip time, elevation change and a description of the 15 trail experiences.  

The fourth panel: Bryce Amphitheater
A map spans the panel showing the park road, trails and services available from the entrance at the Visitor Center to Bryce Point, the northern third of the park.  

The fifth panel: 
Here at Bryce Canyon you can explore the Junior Ranger Trail, discover how prairie dogs communicate, learn about the park on a ranger-guided program, and become a Junior Ranger. There are lots of fun things to see and do. Start at the visitor center where you can learn about programs, hikes, walks, and talks; watch the park film; and explore the interactive museum. Ask for a copy of the Junior Ranger Book, then head out and discover Bryce Canyon.

title: Paria View
listingDescription: A viewpoint for those who want to experience the quieter side of the park, Paria View overlooks a more than 500 ft (152 m) deep amphitheater formed by the headwaters of Yellow Creek, which drains east and south to the Paria River.

images.altText: Vibrant red rock cliffs stand above forests and a broad river valley
images.title: Paria View
images.caption: Paria View is a quieter view of towering limestone cliffs and the broader Paria valley beyond

bodyText:
The road to this viewpoint is closed to vehicles in winter months to provide for winter activities like cross-country skiing and snowshoeing.
A viewpoint for those who want to experience the quieter side of the park, Paria View overlooks a more than 500 ft (152 m) deep amphitheater formed by the headwaters of Yellow Creek, which drains east and south to the Paria River. Yellow Creek's erosion of the Grey Cliffs' softer marine layers directly below you currently undercuts the Pink Cliffs of Bryce Canyon, resulting in large slabs falling away at once. The sheer cliffs created by this undercutting characterize almost all viewpoints south of here. The southern end of the Paria Valley is easier seen here at at viewpoints further south than from the Bryce Amphitheater, and distant views of the dramatic White Cliffs and the dome of Navajo Mountain are wonderful at sunset.

Trails

A short paved path leads to a promontory viewpoint. No other trails depart from this area.

Landscape Features

To the Southeast

The headwaters of Yellow Creek have been at work for millions of years, slowly pushing back into the Paunsaugunt plateau and carving the deep amphitheater below you. Due to softer marine layers of rock below the iron-rich Claron formation's limestone cliffs, these rocks are being undercut and sheer away rather than slope in the ways seen within the Bryce Amphitheater to the north. Yellow Creek drains into the Paria River, and the Paria Valley and the upper steps of the Grand Staircase exposed within it present most of the view beyond this amphitheater. Observe the shale-rich badlands of the Grey Cliffs slowly transform to the sometimes iron-rich sandstones of the upper White Cliffs (Kodachrome State Park is located in this transition zone) which then transition into the less iron-rich white sandstones and deep canyons carved within the Navajo Formation further off. Navajo Mountain looms on the distant horizon over 80 miles (129 km) away near Page, Arizona. Called a laccolith, Navajo Mountain can be thought of as a volcano that never quite happened. As the Colorado Plateau was uplifted over the last 20 million years, a plume of molten rock moved upward from deep inside the Earth causing a swelling much like a large blister. Unlike a volcano, Navajo Mountain never blew its top and so the plume cooled slowly, creating the hard core of the mountain that still exists today.
audioDescription: Here one prominent castle-like hoodoo rises high above a steep and relatively narrow amphitheater. Down and to the southeast is the Yellow Creek and Paria River watershed. Yellow Creek begins in the Paria Amphitheater, and joins the Paria River further on where it carves down through the Grey and White Cliffs of the Grand Staircase in the distance.

title: Peek-A-Boo Loop Hike the Hoodoos
listingDescription: Hike the Hoodoos Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

images.altText: A wayside showing a twisted ponderosa pine tree describes the Hike the Hoodoos program
images.title: Peekaboo Loop Hike the Hoodoos wayside
images.caption: Peekaboo Loop Hike the Hoodoos wayside (be sure to include yourself in your photo!)

bodyText:
I Hiked the Hoodoos

Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

1. Hike a minimum of 3 mi / 4.8 km, or find at least 3 benchmarks and complete steps 2 through 4 below.

2. Each individual must have either a pencil rubbing of the benchmark (see Jr. Ranger Book) or a"selfie"with the benchmark.

3. Only special "I Hiked the Hoodoos" benchmarks qualify for the reward.

4. Rewards are available at the Visitor Center!

See your park newspaper or Junior Ranger book for more information. Benchmarks are located on Mossy Cave, Rim Trail, Tower Bridge, Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, Peekaboo Loop, Sheep Creek, and the Bristlecone Loop trails.
audioDescription: Peek-A-Boo Loop Hike the Hoodoos wayside 382 words This Hike the Hoodoo exhibit is on the eastern side of Peekaboo Loop along a winding portion of the trail in a flat area of natural sediment. Just beyond the exhibit is a uniquely-shaped ponderosa pine. Due to an early injury, it’s trunk has grown low to the ground in a corkscrew shape. Exhibit title: Hike the Hoodoos, Peekaboo Loop, promotes the parks Hike the Hoodoos challenge. There are nine "Hike the Hoodoos" benchmarks located along eight different hiking trails in the park. Each exhibit has a large round coin-like metal, medallion called a benchmark inserted into the panel. The right side of the panel illustrates a natural feature found at the location. Here a close-up photograph of a ponderosa pine tree. Its trunk and limbs twist along the orange rock of the canyon. Dark reddish-brown bark is deeply furrowed. Text reads: Why do some of the ponderosa pine trees along this trail twist like coils of rope? While the answer is not certain, the trees might be aiming to stay upright on a slumping slope, or they could be growing faster on one side to compensate for roots that have died on the other period what is your theory about the trees shape? The left side of each panel provides a trail map with current location, the benchmark and a description of the hoodoo challenge: This map shows our location in between inspiration point and sunset point on the Peekaboo loop trail. Text reads: You have found the Peekaboo Loop benchmark (metal disk below) on the “I hiked the hoodoos” challenge -- a way to stay healthy and have fun in your National Park. To meet the challenge: either find 3 benchmarks, or hike 3 miles on trails that have benchmarks see map and park newspaper or junior Ranger booklet bring rubbings of the benchmarks or photos of yourself with them to the visitor center to receive a small reward. The coin-shaped metal benchmark is mounted to the panel. Words have been etched into the metal: Bryce Canyon National Park Peek a Boo I hiked the hoodoos elevation 7682 feet above sea level. Text continues: This project was made possible in part by a grant from the National Park foundation through the generous support of the Coca Cola foundation.

title: Peekaboo Loop, Hat Shop, and Under-the-Rim Trail Trailhead
listingDescription: Here the Peekaboo Loop, Hat Shop, and Under the Rim Trails all descend from the Bryce Point area.

images.altText: A forested depression surrounded by bright orange and pink limestone cliffs and rock spires
images.title: Hat Shop Hoodoos
images.caption: HIkers heading down the Under-the-Rim Trail will find the Hat Shop hoodoos two miles down trail

bodyText:
Peekaboo Loop Trail

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 5.5 miles (8.8 km)
Elevation change: 1,555 feet (473 m)
Average time: 3-4 hours

The Peekaboo Loop trail quickly descends over 1,000 feet (305 m) to the floor of the Bryce Amphitheater before travelling north into one of the densest areas of hoodoo formation in the park. Here shaded north-facing slopes retain precipitation and support a diverse forest among these colorful spires of rock. The trail takes its name from the surprises that await around its many turns and elevation changes. In summer, these surprises may include horse and mule riders, which is why a clockwise direction of travel is recommended. This direction also provides for the best views of the Wall of Windows, one of the most iconic features along this strenuous trail. Hikers may choose to connect to either the Queen's Garden or Navajo Loop trails at the loop's northern junction. More about the trail

Hat Shop Trail

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 4 miles (6.4 km)
Elevation Change: 1,436 feet (428 m)
Average Time: 3-4 hours

The Hat Shop Trail offers long views overlooking the colorful cliffs of the Grand Staircase to the south and a quiet solitude in which to enjoy them. Hikers descend nearly 1500 feet (457 meters) as they travel the first 2 miles (3.2 km) of the much longer 23 mile (37 km) Under-the-Rim backcountry Trail before turning around to climb 2 miles (3.2 km) back. At the turnaround point, balanced-rock hoodoos cluster along the trail's edge. These narrow, orange pinnacles wear "hats" of large grey boulders, giving them a distinct appearance compared to hoodoos seen in the Bryce Amphitheater to the north. Visitors interested in backcountry camping experiences along the Under-the-Rim Trail should first obtain a permit at the Visitor Center. More about the trail

Under-the-Rim Trail

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 22.9 miles (37 km)
Ascent: 5,884 feet (1,793 m)
Average time: 2-3 days

This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m).
Experience the solitude of Bryce's forested backcountry on the Under-the-Rim Trail. Descending from the rim, this trail meanders through forests and meadows, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance. The Under the Rim Trail follows the base of the Paunsaugant Plateau and is largely forested. The hoodoos are part of the distant vistas to the west as you hike the valley floor. To preserve this experience, backcountry camping is permitted only in designated campsites. A backcountry permit must be obtained at the Visitor Center prior to any overnight trips. This trail is not as easily followed as developed trails within the Bryce Amphitheater.

Note: the Agua Connecting Trail is closed until further notice.

Camping (Permits Available at Visitor Center)

There are 8 campsites on the 22.9 mile (36.9 km) Under-the-Rim Trail.

 

Backcountry Hiking and Camping

The Under-the-Rim Trail is approximately 22.9 miles (36.9 km) from Bryce Point to Rainbow Point. Connecting trails offer access from the park's Scenic Drive and intersect the Under-the-Rim Trail at Swamp Canyon, and Whiteman Bench. Agua Canyon Connector Trail **is closed** until further notice due to storm damage.

The Riggs Spring Loop is an 8.6 mile (13.9 km) hike beginning and ending at the Rainbow and Yovimpa Point parking lot at the south end of the Scenic Drive. Either the Yovimpa or Rainbow Point trailhead may be used to access this loop.

A backcountry hiking map with mileage is available at the Visitor Center. More information

Permits Required

A Backcountry Permit is required for all overnight stays in the backcountry. Permits may be purchased at the Visitor Center from 9 am - 12:30 pm and 1:30 pm to 6 pm. Backcountry campsites are limited to 6 people per regular site, and 15 people per group site.

No Fires Permitted

Though gas-powered cooking stoves are allowed, no open fires are allowed anywhere in the park outside of North and Sunset Campground's established fire rings.

Bears and Other Wildlife

Bryce Canyon is home to many animals including mountain lions, coyotes and black bears. Squirrels, snakes and other small animals may also be present near your campsite.
Due to the presence of black bears within Bryce Canyon National Park, the use of bear-resistant food canisters on overnight backcountry hikes is highly recommended. Bear-resistant canisters are available for loan, free of charge, at the Visitor Center.

Transportation

April through October the free park shuttle services Bryce Point. No park-provided transportation is provided south of Bryce Point. You can arrange a private shuttle using approved providers listed on our Commercial Tours and Services page.

title: Peekaboo and Hat Shop wayside
listingDescription: The Peekaboo Loop provides a steep adventure to the floor of Bryce Amphitheater. Both sides of this strenuous loop provide many climbs and descents through a forest of hoodoos. Return up to Bryce Point or connect to Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, or Tropic trails at the northern junction. Clockwise travel is requested due to horse use. The Hat Shop Trail descends 1,000 feet (305 m) along the first 2 miles (3.2 km) of the much longer 23-mile (37 km) Under-the-Rim Trail.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit providing orientation and accessibility information to trails.
images.title: Peekaboo and Hat Shop trailhead
images.caption: The Peekaboo Loop provides a steep adventure to the floor of Bryce Amphitheater.

bodyText:
The Peekaboo Loop provides a steep adventure to the floor of the Bryce Amphitheater. Both sides of this strenuous loop provide many climbs and descents through a forest of hoodoos. Return up to Bryce Point or connect to Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, or Tropic trails at the northern junction. Clockwise travel is requested due to horse use. 

The Hat Shop Trail descends 1,000 feet (305 m) along the first 2 miles (3.2 km) of the much longer 23-mile (37 km) Under-the-Rim Trail to balanced rock hoodoos along the right side of the trail. Return by hiking back up to Bryce Point. Visitors interested in backcountry camping must first obtain a permit. Visit nps.gov/brca or go to the visitor center for more information.
audioDescription: From Bryce Point is one of the most scenic vistas of the main Bryce amphitheater. Visitors stand on a narrow fin of rock facing out into the amphitheater, which is an expansive bowl-like feature carved into the edge of the high plateau. The canyon is filled with thousands of irregularly eroded spires of rocks called hoodoos. Each spire and cliff face continues layered striations of orange, white, gray, and brown fading to soft rolling hills of forest in the distant valley. Two trailhead Orientation panels and one interpretive panel are here at Bryce Point; The Rim Trail and the Peekaboo and Hat Shop Trail access are at this location, one of the most iconic of the park’s viewpoints. First, at the parking area at the entrance to the trailhead is the orientation to the Peekaboo and Hat Shop Trails. A map illustrates that we are at the Bryce Point overlook. A graphic provides details about each trail: Length: Peekaboo is 5.5 miles (8.8 km) Difficulty: Strenuous Total Ascent: 1,571 feet (479 meters) Hat Shop is 4.0 miles (6.4 km) roundtrip Difficulty: Strenuous Total Ascent: 1,075 feet (328 m) A photograph along the bottom of the panel highlights the Wall of windows; a series of lightly colored hoodoos and sandstone arches or windows in the rock spires found along Peekaboo Trail. An inset photographs shows a sampling of the Hat Shop hoodoos. This collection of hoodoos have delicately balanced caprocks on their tops which resemble hats. A bronze coin-shaped medallion on the panel signals that Two “Hike the Hoodoos” medallions are found along this trail. Find them, then take a photo or rubbing. When you’ve found three different medallions or hiked 3 miles (4.8 km) on trails that have benchmarks (see Visitor Guide) take them to the visitor center for a reward. Text continues: The Peekaboo Loop provides a steep adventure to the floor of Bryce Amphitheater. Both sides of this strenuous loop provide many climbs and descents through a forest of hoodoos. Return up to Bryce Point or connect to Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, or Tropic trails at the northern junction. Clockwise travel is requested due to horse use. The Hat Shop Trail descends 1,000 feet (305 m) along the first 2 miles (3.2 km) of the much longer 23-mile (37 km) Under-the-Rim Trail to balanced rock hoodoos along the right side of the trail. Return by hiking back up to Bryce Point. Visitors interested in backcountry camping must first obtain a permit. Visit nps.gov/brca or go to the visitor center for more information.

title: People of Bryce wayside
listingDescription: People have been here for thousands of years. Many tribes, including Southern Paiutes, Hopi, Ute, and Zuni, call this area home. Over 150 years ago, early settlers from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints came here. They built nearby communities, many of which are still here. Today this place is a national park. It is protected for you and people around the world to enjoy.

images.caption: Many tribes, including Southern Paiutes, Hopi, Ute, and Zuni, call this area home.

audioDescription: People of Bryce A series of four panels illustrated for children are along an 0.8 mile section of the shared use path between the Visitor Center and Sunrise Point area. The artwork is pen and ink with soft watercolor tones. Each exhibit highlights Junior Ranger activities from the park book available at the Visitor Center. Exhibit themes focus on the ethnic and racial diversity of park visitors, the Southern Paiute lifeways, common birds, and mammals of the park and leave no trace principals. An illustration that fills the panel shows a diversity of people hiking along the Rim trail. Many ages, abilities and ethnicities are represented. Text reads: People of Bryce People have been here for thousands of years. title: Pinyon Juniper Forest wayside
listingDescription: Bryce Canyon’s elevation ranges 2,500 feet (762 m) from Rainbow Point to the canyon bottoms, creating a wide range of temperatures and precipitation resulting in three climatic or life zones—Pinyon/Juniper, Ponderosa Pine, Mixed Conifer. More than a thousand plant species inhabit the park, while dozens of animals, including over 100 species of birds, move throughout these zones.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit showing the plants and animals of the pinyon juniper forest
images.title: Pinyon Juniper Forest
images.caption: The Pinyon Juniper Forest/Life zone.

bodyText:
Bryce Canyon’s elevation ranges 2,500 feet (762 m) from Rainbow Point to the canyon bottoms, creating a wide range of temperatures and precipitation resulting in three climatic or life zones—Pinyon/Juniper, Ponderosa Pine, Mixed Conifer. More than a thousand plant species inhabit the park, while dozens of animals, including over 100 species of birds, move throughout these zones.

The Mossy Cave Trail winds through a through a forest community defined by pinyon pine and juniper. Look for short evergreen trees and a variety of desert and upland shrubs. Springs and irrigation water found here also create refuges for more water-dependent plants.
audioDescription: The first exhibit before the bridge along the trail to Mossy Cave highlights the Pinyon /Juniper Life Zone A relief map of the park marks our location at 6000 ft elevation where this Pinyon /Juniper life zone is possible. The map also marks the next two life zones that occur at higher elevations: Ponderosa Pine life zone at 8000ft and then the Mixed Conifer life zone at 8,500ft. A background photograph shows a cluster of shrubs and trees you may find along the trail that illustrate the diversity of species found here: Juniper, Ponderosa pine, Greenleaf manzanita, gambel oak and Pinyon Pine with its buff colored cones and the spikey narrowleaf yucca. Animals are featured that include a Uinta chipmunk, Greater short-horned lizard and a Pinyon Jay with a special note not to feed the animals. Text continues: Bryce Canyon’s elevation ranges 2,500 feet (762 m) from Rainbow Point to the canyon bottoms, creating a wide range of temperatures and precipitation resulting in three climatic or life zones—Pinyon/Juniper, Ponderosa Pine, Mixed Conifer. More than a thousand plant species inhabit the park, while dozens of animals, including over 100 species of birds, move throughout these zones. The Mossy Cave Trail winds through a through a forest community defined by pinyon pine and juniper. Look for short evergreen trees and a variety of desert and upland shrubs. Springs and irrigation water found here also create refuges for more water-dependent plants.

title: Piracy Point
listingDescription: With a little imagination two large buttes appear as sailing ships engaged in a naval battle. Another origin for the name might from from the fact that this point overlooks the Sheep Creek drainage system to the north and the Willis Creek drainage system that collects all run-off from Rainbow Point south from here. The northern extent of the Willis Creek drainage is beginning to be diverted toward Sheep Creek in a process called "stream piracy". This is when a river drainage

images.altText: Forested limestone cliffs stand above a broad canyon and below a distant plateau along the horizon
images.title: Piracy Point
images.caption: Piracy Point provides a view looking north down Swamp Canyon

bodyText:
Piracy Point has been said to take its name from the buttes that might resemble pirate ships sailing alongside the rim, but it's more likely that the name refers to a geomorphological process that is soon to take place here. This point overlooks Swamp Canyon and the Sheep Creek drainage system to the north and the Willis Creek drainage system that collects run-off south from here. The broad, sloping valley to the north of you currently drains to Sheep Creek, but on the other side of the cliffs right of it, tributaries of Willis Creek are steadily encroaching. Someday soon, the Willis Creek drainage will begin to divert water through a process called "stream piracy". This is when a river drainage system or watershed is diverted from its own bed, and flows instead down the bed of a neighboring stream. Swamp Canyon is also one of the only places in the park where water flowing on top of the plateau is diverted over the rim to the east (rather than travelling west as part of the Sevier River).

This is also the transitional zone between Ponderosa Pine Forests and the Spruce-Fir forest. Watch for representatives of both plant and animal communities. Here you might find flowers such as Showy Goldeneye and Shrubby Cinquefoil. Also watch for Osprey. If you are surprised to find fish eaters like Osprey living in a desert-like environment you're not the only one. Not too far from here nest a pair of Osprey that catch and carry fish from Tropic Reservoir - a distance of two air miles!

Trails

A very short and flat but unpaved trail leads south back to Farview Point.
audioDescription: A very short and flat trail leads north from the parking lot at Farview to Piracy Point where two large buttes have been described to be shaped like two sailing ships in battle. Ponderosa Pine trees and spruce trees are abundant here.
