title: Ponderosa Canyon
listingDescription: Ponderosa Canyon is so named because of the huge Ponderosa Pines on the canyon floor. Some of these trees measure more than 5 ft. in diameter and exceed heights of 150 ft.

images.altText: Vibrant red rock cliffs stand above forests with a distant plateau along the horizon
images.title: Ponderosa Canyon
images.caption: Ponderosa Canyon not only provides views of cliffs below, but of distant features along the horizon

bodyText:
Ponderosa Canyon is so named because of the huge Ponderosa Pines on the canyon floor. Some of these trees measure more than 5 ft. in diameter and exceed heights of 150 ft. However from high above at the viewpoint you would never know this. In fact many are confused by the name, not expecting to find themselves surrounded by a forest of Engelmann spruce and Douglas-fir. Certain types of vegetation grow in certain environments according to conditions such as moisture and temperature. These conditions are strongly controlled by elevation. Forests, therefore, are divided into zones or forest types according to elevation, because a forest's dominant tree species varies with these changes in elevation.

Bryce Canyon National Park encompasses three of these forest types from the lowest elevations below the rim of the canyon to the upper elevations in the southernmost end of the park. At the bottom is the Pinyon-Juniper Woodland Belt, dominated by the Pinyon Pine and the Utah Juniper. The rim of the canyon in the northern end of the park is dominated by the Ponderosa Pine, and is thus classified as the Ponderosa Pine Forest. At the highest elevations, like here at Ponderosa Point, Engelmann Spruce, Douglas-fir and White Fir are the most common tree species, indicative of a Mixed Conifer Forest.

Trails

Trail Closed due to Rockfall
From here, the Agua Connector Trail descends 1.6 miles (4.0 km) to its junction with the Under the Rim Trail approximately 1,000 feet (305 m) below.

Landscape Features

To the South

See the hoodoos eroded from the edge of the Paunsaugunt plateau contained within a bowl-shaped amphitheater shared with Rainbow Point. A forest floor of pine and fir lies 1,000 feet (305 m) below.

To the Southeast

Navajo Mountain looms on the distant horizon over 80 miles (129 km) away near Page, Arizona. Called a laccolith, Navajo Mountain can be thought of as a volcano that never quite happened. As the Colorado Plateau was uplifted over the last 20 million years, a plume of molten rock moved upward from deep inside the Earth causing a swelling much like a large blister. Unlike a volcano, Navajo Mountain never blew its top and so the plume cooled slowly, creating the hard core of the mountain that still exists today.

To the East

The Paria Valley and the upper steps of the Grand Staircase exposed within it present most of the view. Across the valley, the Table Cliff plateau stands at 10,000 feet (3048 m) and is composed of the same Claron formation (or "Pink Cliffs") as Bryce Canyon's hoodoos. This difference in elevation is due to the presence of the Paunsaugunt fault--a major normal fault that runs northeast to southwest along the park's eastern boundary. Uplift of the Colorado Plateau over the last 20 million years is responsible for the nearly 2,000 feet (607 m) of elevation difference expressed by this fault. Below these Pink Cliffs, observe the shale-rich badlands of the Grey Cliffs slowly transform to the sometimes iron-rich sandstones of the upper White Cliffs. Kodachrome State Park is located in this transition zone.
Almost the same distance to Navajo Mountain in the southeast, the Henry Mountains can be seen on days with good air quality, 86 miles (138 km) away beyond the eastern horizon. Like Navajo Mountain, these too are laccoliths--or plumes of molten rock that warped the rocks above them, but never broke through as a volcano would. As with the terrain of Capitol Reef National Park, which lies just in front of these peaks, millions of years of erosion have now occurred, and at the Henry Mountains it has removed the overlying rock and exposed the hard igneous cores within these mountains.

To the North

Observe the eroded edge of the Paunsaugunt Plateau, punctuated by bowl-shaped amphitheaters.

To the West

The rolling ponderosa forest of the Paunsaugunt plateau is deeply incised here by water travelling north to the Tropic Reservoir. The direction of flow is decided by the plateau's upward tilt to the south and has created a rain divide between the Great Basin of Nevada and the Colorado River that follows the edge of this plateau.

Backcountry Hiking and Camping

The Under-the-Rim Trail is approximately 22.9 miles (36.9 km) from Bryce Point to Rainbow Point. Connecting trails offer access from the park's Scenic Drive and intersect the Under-the-Rim Trail at Swamp Canyon, and Whiteman Bench. Agua Canyon Connector Trail **is closed** until further notice due to storm damage.

The Riggs Spring Loop is an 8.6 mile (13.9 km) hike beginning and ending at the Rainbow and Yovimpa Point parking lot at the south end of the Scenic Drive. Either the Yovimpa or Rainbow Point trailhead may be used to access this loop.

A backcountry hiking map with mileage is available at the Visitor Center. More information

Permits Required

A Backcountry Permit is required for all overnight stays in the backcountry. Permits may be purchased at the Visitor Center from 9 am - 12:30 pm and 1:30 pm to 6 pm. Backcountry campsites are limited to 6 people per regular site, and 15 people per group site.

No Fires Permitted

Though gas-powered cooking stoves are allowed, no open fires are allowed anywhere in the park outside of North and Sunset Campground's established fire rings.

Bears and Other Wildlife

Bryce Canyon is home to many animals including mountain lions, coyotes and black bears. Squirrels, snakes and other small animals may also be present near your campsite.
Due to the presence of black bears within Bryce Canyon National Park, the use of bear-resistant food canisters on overnight backcountry hikes is highly recommended. Bear-resistant canisters are available for loan, free of charge, at the Visitor Center.

Transportation

No park-provided transportation is provided south of Bryce Point. You can arrange a private shuttle using approved providers listed on our Commercial Tours and Services page.
audioDescription:
A sign at this overlook reads Ponderosa Point Elevation 8904 ft
The canyon floor is covered in Ponderosa Pine while white fir and Douglas fir occupy this area due to the higher elevations.

The cliff faces have horizontal layers of color of varying thickness from white, yellows and oranges. In the distance is a tree covered plateau known as the Table Cliff Plateau, with Powell Point at its southern end. To its right are the distant Henry Mountains.

title: Ponderosa Pine Life Zone wayside

images.altText: A wayside exhibit providing information about the Ponderosa pine life zone.
images.title: Ponderosa Pine Life Zones
images.caption: The Ponderosa pine community/life zone.

bodyText:
Here at Bryce Canyon, elevation ranges from 9,100 feet (2,778 m) at Rainbow Point to 6,600 feet (2012 m) in the canyon bottoms. This creates three distinctive climatic or life zones—Mixed Conifer (highest elevation), Ponderosa Pine (mid-elevation), and Pinyon/Juniper (lowest elevation.) More than a thousand plant species inhabit the park, while many animal species, including 100 species of birds, move throughout these zones.

Ponderosa pine forests define this community. These stately evergreens in front of you can grow 200 feet tall (61 m) and often live up to 500 years. Ponderosa pines have adapted to depend upon low-intensity fires, typically started by lightning. Fire maintains an open forest floor, clearing dense growth, so that grasses, wildflowers, and new trees can flourish. Fire's rejuvenating effect on this ecosystem attracts and supports diverse wildlife.
audioDescription: This panel along the Rim trail between Sunrise and Sunset Point provides and introduction to the three life zones found within the park. A relief map of the park marks our location here at 8000 ft elevation in the Ponderosa Pine life zone. The map also marks the next two life zones that occur within the park, the Pinyon Juniper life zone at a lower elevation of 6000ft and the Mixed Conifer life zone at 8,500ft. A background photograph shows a Ponderosa Pine forest with lower growing Greenleaf manzanita shrubs in the understory. A close-up of the pine bark is emphasized with a caption that reads: The thick, plated bark of ponderosa pine is an adaptation that protects the tree from fire. The crevices of the bark emit a fragrance similar to butterscotch or vanilla. A series of photographs feature other plants and animals found here to include Indian rice grass, the small blue berries of the Oregon grape and the soft yellow flowers of the Antelope bitterbush. A gold-mantled ground squirrel eats a nut on a rock, a mule deer grazes in a meadow and a bird, the Pygmy nuthatch with a white underbelly, straight sharp bill and slate gray back sits on a branch, while a special note reminds us not to feed the animals. Text continues: Here at Bryce Canyon, elevation ranges from 9,100 feet (2,778 m) at Rainbow Point to 6,600 feet (2012 m) in the canyon bottoms. This creates three distinctive climatic or life zones—Mixed Conifer (highest elevation), Ponderosa Pine (mid-elevation), and Pinyon/Juniper (lowest elevation.) More than a thousand plant species inhabit the park, while many animal species, including 100 species of birds, move throughout these zones. Ponderosa pine forests define this community. These stately evergreens in front of you can grow 200 feet tall (61 m) and often live up to 500 years. Ponderosa pines have adapted to depend upon low-intensity fires, typically started by lightning. Fire maintains an open forest floor, clearing dense growth, so that grasses, wildflowers, and new trees can flourish. Fire's rejuvenating effect on this ecosystem attracts and supports diverse wildlife.

title: Publicizing Bryce wayside

images.altText: Wayside exhibit describes the rise of tourism in the park in the early 1900’s.
images.title: Publicizing Bryce
images.caption: In 1920, the Syrett's constructed Tourists' Rest. Ruby's Inn serves visitors to this day.

bodyText:
In July 1915, Joseph William (J.W.) Humphrey, a US Forest Service supervisor, visited Bryce Canyon for the first time. He wrote, “You can perhaps imagine my surprise at the indescribable beauty. . . . It was sundown before I could be dragged from the canyon view . . .” Under his direction, photos, a film, and articles publicized the beauty of Bryce and funding was found for road improvements and early trails.

Tourism increased, and local homesteaders Rueben (“Ruby”) and Minnie Syrett saw an opportunity. They erected tents and supplied meals for guests near Sunset Point, and in 1920 constructed Tourists' Rest, a lodge with tent cabins. When Bryce Canyon became a national monument in 1923, the Union Pacific Railroad purchased Tourists' Rest to construct the park's now historic lodge and cabins. The Syrett's visitor accommodations were relocated just north of the park, and Ruby's Inn serves visitors to this day.
audioDescription: This panel along the Rim trail between Sunrise and Sunset Point, near the path to the Lodge describes the rise of tourism in the park in the early 1900’s and those that made it happen. Title reads: Publicizing Bryce A black and white photograph of the sweeping rugged landscape shows four early park visitors from the 1920’s; two stand along the canyon edge while the other two sit beside their guide as he kneels and points his fingers out into landscape. Four black and white images feature local homesteader Ruby Syrett dressed in cowboy hat, chaps and boots standing beside the Post office at Rubys Inn, two workers and a child stand outside of Ruby’s Inn, while park visitors and a guide stand beside a bare tree along the edge of the canyon while guests sit in rocking chairs near the radio inside Bryce Lodge. A black and white portrait of US Forest Service Employee JW Humphrey in a suit overlays the image. With a quote that reads: I shall always feel that the part I played in introducing Bryce Canyon to the world is the greatest accomplishment of my life. J.W. Humphrey Text continues In July 1915, Joseph William (J.W.) Humphrey, a US Forest Service supervisor, visited Bryce Canyon for the first time. He wrote, “You can perhaps imagine my surprise at the indescribable beauty. . . . It was sundown before I could be dragged from the canyon view . . .” Under his direction, photos, a film, and articles publicized the beauty of Bryce and funding was found for road improvements and early trails. Tourism increased, and local homesteaders Rueben (“Ruby”) and Minnie Syrett saw an opportunity. They erected tents and supplied meals for guests near Sunset Point, and in 1920 constructed Tourists' Rest, a lodge with tent cabins. When Bryce Canyon became a national monument in 1923, the Union Pacific Railroad purchased Tourists' Rest to construct the park's now historic lodge and cabins. The Syrett's visitor accommodations were relocated just north of the park, and Ruby's Inn serves visitors to this day.

bodyText: Although many find it challenging, this is the least strenuous trail descending into the Bryce Amphitheater. This trail follows a ridge 0.9 mile (1.4 km) down to the Queen Victoria hoodoo where hikers can either turn around and return or continue on to the Navajo Loop (Queen's/Navajo Combination Loop) or the Peekaboo Loop (Figure-8 Combination). See the Visitor Guide for information on combination loops.
audioDescription: Although many find it challenging, this is the least strenuous trail descending into the Bryce Amphitheater. This trail follows a ridge 0.9 mile (1.4 km) down to the Queen Victoria hoodoo where hikers can either turn around and return or continue on to the Navajo Loop (Queen's/Navajo Combination Loop) or the Peekaboo Loop (Figure-8 Combination). See the Visitor Guide for information on combination loops. An inset photographs shows a closeup of the Queen Victoria hoodoo, a stone formation that is said to resemble a statue of the standing queen facing left with hands crossed at her waste, in a long flowing dress. A bronze coin-shaped medallion on the panel signals that One “Hike the Hoodoos” medallion is found along this trail. Find it, then take a photo or rubbing. When you’ve found three different medallions or hiked 3 miles (4.8 km) on trails that have benchmarks (see Visitor Guide) take them to the visitor center for a reward. title: Queens Garden Hike the Hoodoos
listingDescription: Hike the Hoodoos Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

images.altText: A wayside showing a red rock spire beside a statue of Queen Victoria explaining Hike the Hoodoos
images.title: Queen's Garden HIked the Hoodoos
images.caption: Queen's Garden Hike the Hoodoos wayside (be sure to include yourself in your photo!)

bodyText:
I Hiked the Hoodoos

Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

1. Hike a minimum of 3 mi / 4.8 km, or find at least 3 benchmarks and complete steps 2 through 4 below.

2. Each individual must have either a pencil rubbing of the benchmark (see Jr. Ranger Book) or a"selfie"with the benchmark.

3. Only special "I Hiked the Hoodoos" benchmarks qualify for the reward.

4. Rewards are available at the Visitor Center!

See your park newspaper or Junior Ranger book for more information. Benchmarks are located on Mossy Cave, Rim Trail, Tower Bridge, Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, Peekaboo Loop, Sheep Creek, and the Bristlecone Loop trails.
audioDescription: The exhibit panel is along a short spur trail at the end of the Queen's Garden Trail in a flat area of natural sediment among many tall hoodoos, described as the Queen's Garden. To the north is a unique hoodoo said to resemble Queen Victoria. The exhibit: Hike the Hoodoos, Queens Garden, promotes the parks Hike the Hoodoos challenge. There are nine "Hike the Hoodoos" benchmarks located along eight different hiking trails in the park. Each exhibit has a large round coin-like metal, medallion called a benchmark inserted into the panel. The right side of the panel illustrates a natural feature found at the location. Here a photograph of the hoodoo that has been named Queen Victoria, after a statue in London, England. A photo of the actual statue of the queen is beside the hoodoo for comparison. The statue of the standing queen, facing left with hands crossed at her waste, in a long flowing dress is beside a photo of the queen Victoria hoodoo rock formation that bears a strong resemblance to the outline of the statue. Text reads: At Bryce Canyon, weathering can alter huge rocks within a human lifetime. Rain and Frost wedging carved these stones into curious shapes including the Queen Victoria who do, which was named for a statue in London, England. If you use your imagination, you might see the hoodoo queen riding an animal. What kind? How many years do you think it will take the Queens shape to change? The left side of each panel provides a trail map with your location, the benchmark and describes the hoodoo challenge: The map shows our location in between Sunrise and Sunset Point on the Queens garden trail. Text reads: You have found the Queens garden benchmark (metal disk below) on the “I hiked the hoodoos” challenge -- a way to stay healthy and have fun in your National Park. To meet the challenge: either find 3 benchmarks, or hike 3 miles on trails that have benchmarks see map and park newspaper or junior Ranger booklet bring rubbings of the benchmarks or photos of yourself with them to the visitor center to receive a small reward. The coin-shaped metal benchmark is mounted to the panel. Words have been etched into the metal: Bryce Canyon National Park Queen Victoria I hiked the hoodoos elevation 7635 feet above sea level. This project was made possible in part by a grant from the National Park foundation through the generous support of the Coca Cola foundation.

title: Queens Garden Trailhead
listingDescription: One of the park's most popular trails, the Queen's Garden trail descends and bends 0.9 miles (1.4 km) along a ridgeline down to a unique hoodoo said to resemble Queen Victoria. Of the six trails that descend into the Bryce Amphitheater, the Queen's Garden Trail is considered the least strenuous; though due to the park's high elevation and steep grades in some areas, it is still categorized as a moderately strenuous hike.

images.altText: A glowing landscape of red and orange rock spires and forest
images.title: Queen's Garden Trail
images.caption: The Queen's Garden descends a long ridgeline past fins and hoodoos within the Bryce Amphitheater

bodyText:
Queen's Garden Trail

Difficulty: Moderate
Total Distance: 1.8 miles (3.0 km)
Elevation change: 320 feet (98 m)
Average time: 1-2 hours

One of the park's most popular trails, the Queen's Garden trail descends and bends 0.9 miles (1.4 km) along a ridgeline down to a unique hoodoo said to resemble Queen Victoria (be sure to travel down the spur trail at the bottom of the trail to see this hoodoo). The varied and colorful rock formations that surround this hoodoo, are described as many sculptures and other ornaments within the Queen's "Garden". Of the six trails that descend into the Bryce Amphitheater, the Queen's Garden Trail is considered the least strenuous; though due to the park's high elevation and steep grades in some areas, it is still categorized as a moderately strenuous hike (other Bryce Amphitheater trails include the Tower Bridge Trail, Navajo Loop Trail, Fairyland Loop Trail, Tower Bridge Trail, and Peekaboo Loop Trail). The trail also provides views of a grove of bristlecone pines near the Horse Trail junction.
More about the trail

Combination Loops

This trail can be combined with the Navajo Loop to form the 2.9 mile (4.6 km) Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop and the Peekaboo Loop to form the 6.4 mile (10.2 km) Figure-8 Combination Loop.

Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop

Difficulty: Moderate
Total Distance: 2.9 miles (4.6 km)
Elevation change: 600 feet (138 m)
Average time: 2-3 hours
Perhaps the park's most popular and iconic trail, the Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop can begin at either Sunrise or Sunset Point but is recommended in a clockwise direction; this is done by descending on the Queen's Garden Trail and ascending the Navajo Loop Trail (Two Bridges side recommended for year-round use and iconic views of Thor's Hammer; Wall Street side is only open in summer). Whether one begins at Sunset or Sunrise Point, these two viewpoints are connected by a flat, 0.5 mile (0.8 km) section of the Rim Trail that completes the loop. If one begins at Sunset Point, they should begin by hiking this section of the Rim Trail to Sunrise Point.
More about the trail

Figure-8 Combination Loop

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 6.4 miles (10.2 km)
Elevation change: 320 feet (98 m)
Average time: 4-5 hours
The Figure-8 Combination combines the Peekaboo Loop Trail with the Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop to create a 6.4 mile (10.2 km) combination of two loops. Like the Queen's / Navajo Combination Loop, the Peekaboo Loop should be hiked in a clockwise direction. One can begin at either Sunset or Sunrise Point. From Sunset Point, one would begin by first hiking the 0.5 mile (0.8 km) section of the Rim Trail that leads north to Sunrise Point, then descend the Queen's Garden Trail to its intersection with the Navajo Loop. A short connecting trail leads from here across Bryce Creek to the Peekaboo Loop Trail. Keeping left will take hikers in a clockwise direction around the strenuous Peekaboo Loop and return them to the intersection of Navajo and Queen's Garden Trails. From here hikers ascend back up to Sunset Point (Two Bridges side recommended for year-round use; Wall Street only open in summer).

Nature

Bristlecone Pines

Note that bristlecone pines share dolomitic limestones with some of the park's most delicate plants. Stay on the trail and help us to protect them.
Though Bryce Canyon is well known for its geology, the park also contains a fantastic diversity of trees. Among the most impressive of these is the Great Basin bristlecone pine (Pinus longaeva). These trees are known for thriving where few other plants can, and for far longer too. Look for bristlecone pines on exposures of dolomitic limestone. These areas of white to grey stone are found in the park's hoodoo-forming Claron formation as low as the Queen's Garden and Fairyland Loop trails. Dolomitic limestone is high in calcium and magnesium, and low in phosphorus. This chemistry is difficult for other plants to tolerate, giving the bristlecone pine plenty of room to grow as slowly as it likes. You'll also typically find higher-elevation bristlecones growing at the edges of cliffs, where competition is even further reduced. Free to take its time, bristlecones pines can grow as slowly as an inch (2.5 cm) per century if conditions are challenging. This gives these trees incredibly dense heartwood, which is capable of providing structural support to the tree long after a section of limb or trunk has lost its life-protecting bark. The oldest tree at Bryce Canyon was estimated to be 1,600 years old, though trees across its range into Nevada and California have been dated at over 5,000 years old, giving Pinus longaeva the honor of being the longest living non-clonal species on Earth.
You can identify a Bristlecone pine by its densely bundled needles of five (making it a white pine). Unlike many other pines that shed their needles every few years, bristlecone pines can retain needles for up to forty years. Their 1.5 in (1.2 cm) long needles remain vibrant and green for typically a full 12 inches (30 cm) along the branch. This appearance is often compared to that of a bottlebrush or pipe cleaner.
Like the limber pine (another white pine found at Bryce Canyon) seeds of the bristlecone pine may be harvested and dispersed to unlikely places by Clark's nutcrackers (Nucifraga columbiana). The seeds of their bristle-tipped cones are often among the first to colonize recently burnt areas.

title: RV Dump Station
listingDescription: This RV Dump Station is typically open spring - fall, closing for the season when overnight temperatures fall below freezing. The dump station is located at the south end of North Campground and can be used by any visitor for a $5 use fee. No use fee applies for those with a campground reservation in the park. Potable water is available.

images.altText: A forested parking lot with a sign reading RV Dump Station
images.title: RV Dump Station
images.caption: The Dump Station is located at the south end of North Campground near the General Store.

bodyText:
The RV Dump Station is closed for winter 2023-2024.

This RV Dump Station is open spring - fall, closing for the season when overnight temperatures fall below freezing and reopening when they rise above freezing. The dump station is located at the south end of North Campground near the General Store.

Cost and Amenities

The RV Dump Station is free for those who have a campsite reservation within the park. Those without a campsite are subject to a $5 use fee. Potable water and a trash can are available.

Alternative dump stations can be found approximately 2 miles north of the park in Bryce Canyon City at the Sinclair gas station or Ruby’s Inn campground.

Beside the lanes, adjacent to the road, is a wooden information kiosk that typically has ranger programs and a newspaper map posted within it.

title: Rainbow Point
listingDescription: At 9,115 ft (2,778 m) this and Yovimpa Point are the highest viewpoints in the park. Tectonic uplift has lifted this entire scene from sea-level over the course of the last 20 million years to later be dissected by tributaries of the Colorado River.

images.altText: White rock red rock spires and forest at viewpoint
images.title: Rainbow Point
images.caption: Rainbow Point looks north from one of the highest viewpoints in the park.

bodyText:
At 9,115 ft (2,778 m) this and Yovimpa Point are the highest viewpoints in the park. Tectonic uplift has lifted this entire scene from sea-level over the course of the last 20 million years to later be dissected by tributaries of the Paria and Colorado Rivers. Tilting that occurred during uplift has situated the southern end of the park approximately 1,000 ft (304 m) higher than its northern end near the Visitor Center. Here erosion has been at work far longer than the Bryce Amphitheater, and undercut sheer cliffs compose much of the view along the edge of the Paunsaugunt Plateau.

Trails

A short path along the plateau edge leads west to the easy 1.0 mi/1.6 km Bristlecone Loop, as well as the 8.8 mi/14.2 km backcountry Riggs Spring Loop and 23 mi/37 km Under-the-Rim Trail.

Landscape Features

To the North

View the eroded edge of the Paunsagunt Plateau, carved by rain and melting snow into bowl-shaped amphitheaters, which drain to the Paria River and then the Colorado River. Atop the Markagunt plateau to the northwest and the Paunsaugunt plateau in the north, the Tushar Mountains and Sevier plateau (or Black Mountains) can be seen. These were created through volcanic activity associated with the uplift of the Colorado Plateau.

To the East

Below the iron-oxide colored limey mudstones of the Pink Cliffs of Bryce Canyon, the valley of the Paria river exposes marine shales of the Grey Cliffs and further south, sandstones of the White Cliffs. The Pink Cliffs as seen in the Table Cliff Plateau can be seen rising to 10,000 ft (3048 m) along the opposite side of the valley.

to the West

Across the Paunsagunt Plateau, peaks of the Black Mountains, and further off the Tushar mountains can be seen. Water which falls upon the forested top of this plateau drains not to the Colorado River, but west and north along the Sevier River towards Nevada. The edge of the plateau is therefore a watershed between the Colorado River and the Great Basin desert of Nevada.

To the South

Views to the south can be best appreciated across the parking lot at Yovimpa Point or along the Bristlecone Loop Trail.
audioDescription:
The Rainbow Point overlook is at the southernmost end of the 18-mile park road. The view faces north spanning the entire length of the park. The overlook is also at the highest elevation within the park. A brown sign reads Rainbow Point Elevation 9,115 feet. A sidewalk leads to the Rainbow Point shelter and exhibit panels that describe the geology, nearby hiking opportunities, and life communities of the canyon. Spruce and fir forests surround the area. A path runs adjacent to the plateau's edge and is enclosed with a horizontal log railing. Nearby, the Yovimpa Point Overlook is the contrasting south facing overlook.

At Rainbow Point Overlook is a sweeping view of the top step of the "Grand Staircase"- a geologic formation that includes the youngest exposed rocks of the Grand Canyon at the bottom step (furthest away), then Zion National Park, the middle step, and the top step of the grand staircase here at Bryce Canyon with the youngest known rock formations.

These intricately carved, horseshoe shaped rock canyons or "amphitheaters" each with horizontal cliffs edges are made of layers of limestone, mudstone, sandstone, silts, and clay stacked in soft pinks, whites, and orange to make up the striking color bands of each plateau, turret, cliff and ridge.

The amphitheaters stretch on for miles. Above, the plateaus are covered in ponderosa and fir forest, ending at cliffs of pink, and hundreds of orange rock pillars called hoodoos, which poke up from the ground like jagged teeth.

An exhibit panel here titled The High Plateaus of Utah further describes the landscape.

bodyText: From here hikers can descend onto the 8.6-mile (13.8 km) Riggs Spring Loop Trail or connect with the rugged 22.9-mile (36.9 km) Under-the-Rim Trail, which travels north to Bryce Point. title: Rainbow Point Orientation wayside
listingDescription: At over 9,000 feet (2,743 m), Rainbow and Yovimpa points are the highest overlooks in the park. While Yovimpa Point looks south across the cliffs of the Grand Staircase, at Rainbow Point views are to the north. Here one can look back on the full length of the Paunsaugunt Plateau's eastern edge. Three trails depart from this area: Bristlecone Loop, Under-the-Rim Trail, and Riggs Spring Loop.

bodyText: At over 9,000 feet (2,743 m), Rainbow and Yovimpa points are the highest overlooks in the park. While Yovimpa Point looks south across the cliffs of the Grand Staircase, at Rainbow Point views are to the north. Here one can look back on the full length of the Paunsaugunt Plateau's eastern edge. Three trails depart from this area: Bristlecone Loop, Under-the-Rim Trail, and Riggs Spring Loop.
audioDescription: Here at the Rainbow Point overlook, there is a trailhead orientation panel and exhibits at the shelter that include a tactile bronze map of the topography of southern Utah’s high plateau province, the three life zone communities found in the park and the processes of deposition, uplift and erosion that created the formations. The Bristlecone loop trailhead access is also nearby. A map illustrates that we are near the Rainbow Point Overlook and Shelter. Picnic area and restrooms are at this location. A graphic provides details about the Bristlecone Loop Trail Length: Bristlecone: 1 mile (1.6 km); Riggs Spring: 8.8 miles (14.2 km); Under-the-Rim: 22.9 miles (36.9 km) Difficulty: Bristlecone: Easy; Riggs Spring: Strenuous; Under-the-Rim: Strenuous Total Ascent: Bristlecone: 200 feet (61 m); Riggs Spring: 2,450 feet (747 m) Under-the-Rim: 5,500 feet (1,676 m) A photograph along the bottom of the panel shows a snowy view from the Rainbow Point overlook: out across the east edge of the Paunsaugunt Plateau An inset photographs shows visitors gathered at the overlook taking in the sweeping view of the top step of the “Grand Staircase”. These intricately carved, horseshoe shaped rock canyons or “amphitheaters” each with horizontal cliffs edges are made of layers of limestone, mudstone, sandstone, silts, and clay stacked in soft pinks, whites, and orange to make up the striking color bands of each plateau, turret, cliff and ridge. The amphitheaters stretch on for miles. Above, the plateaus are covered in ponderosa and fir forest, ending at cliffs of pink, and hundreds of orange rock pillars called hoodoos, which poke up from the ground like jagged teeth. Text Reads: At over 9,000 feet (2,743 m), Rainbow and Yovimpa points are the highest overlooks in the park. While Yovimpa Point looks south across the cliffs of the Grand Staircase, at Rainbow Point views are to the north. Here one can look back on the full length of the Paunsaugunt Plateau's eastern edge. Three trails depart from this area: Bristlecone Loop, Under-the-Rim Trail, and Riggs Spring Loop. A sidewalk leads to the Rainbow Point shelter and exhibit panels that describe the geology, nearby hiking opportunities and life communities of the canyon. Spruce and fir forests surround the area. A path runs adjacent to the plateau’s edge and is enclosed with a horizontal log railing. Nearby the Yovimpa Point Overlook is the contrasting south facing overlook. The Rainbow Point Shelter is a single-story building with an open design on a concrete and stone foundation located directly adjacent to the plateau rim. Massive vertical log posts make up the walls of the building to demonstrate the rustic style architecture found within the park and are painted a dark brown. The walls of the shelter that face the canyon are open and sided with 8inch vertical boards, unpainted. The displays are mounted to these exterior walls. the roof is framed with log rafters and covered with wooden shakes (shingles) painted a spruce green. A comfort station is nearby along the path that borders the parking area.

title: Rainbow Point Shelter

images.altText: A forested, shrubby area surrounds a wooden structure in which a woman stands
images.title: Rainbow Point Shelter
images.caption: The shelter is located at the park's highest elevations, found at Rainbow Point

bodyText:
This historic museum shelter is part of the legacy of the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) at Bryce Canyon. As Bryce Canyon's CCC camp gained experience in rustic construction techniques, more sophisticated projects were attempted. Some woulud see this combination museum-overlook at Rainbow Point, finished in the summer of 1940, as the CCC's outstanding achievement in the park.
After the completion of the museum-overlook at Rainbow Point, no building was erected at Bryce Canyon until the summer of 1947. This was a Standard Oil Service Station sited near the lodge.
The structure was added to the National Register of Historic Places on April 25, 1995.

The Civilian Conservation Corps and Bryce Canyon

Begun in 1933 by President Franklin D. Roosevelt as a task force to work on a wide variety of conservation and public works projects, the CCC's objective was primarily unemployment relief. It provided work for a total of 3 million people--mostly young men during its existence. Crews would create parks, plant forests, and construct roads, trails, shelters, and picnic areas throughout the nation. Bryce Canyon would host camp NP-3, which worked primarily on roads, footpaths, insect control, and landscaping work. Notable projects included the Under-the-Rim Trail from Rainbow Point to Bryce Point, structures at Rainbow Point and the Bristlecone Loop Trail gazebo, and front-country campground development. Camp NP-3 operated from 1934 until the camp was disbanded in 1943. Read More

Safety

Lightning

Please note that this shelter is not a safe place to be during a lightning storm. Summer thunderstorms will produce lightning, which frequently strikes near viewpoints along the rim. If you can hear thunder, return to your car. Read More

Massive vertical log posts make up the walls of the building to demonstrate the rustic style architecture found within the park and are painted a dark brown. The walls of the shelter that face the canyon are open and sided with 8inch vertical boards, unpainted. The displays are mounted to these exterior walls. the roof is framed with log rafters and covered with wooden shakes (shingles) painted a spruce green.

A comfort station is nearby along the path that borders the parking area.

bodyText: A wooden routed sign hanging from a fence just south of Sunset Point designates the meeting point for both Geology Talks and Rim Walks. More about Ranger Programs
audioDescription: A wooden routed sign hanging from a fence just south of Sunset Point designates the meeting point for both Geology Talks and Rim Walks. In summer, wooden half-sawn benches are placed in rows facing the fence where a ranger will stand to deliver talks. Beyond the fence to the east is a varied landscape of red rock spires, cliffs of white and orange, and forest known as the Bryce Amphitheater. To the west is a forest of ponderosa pine. Travelling north leads to Sunset Point and travelling south to Inspiration Point.

title: Riggs Spring Loop Trailhead at Yovimpa
listingDescription: Experience the solitude of Bryce's forested backcountry on the Riggs Spring Loop. Descending from the rim, this 8.8 mile (14.2 km) trail meanders through forests and raised promontories, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance.

images.altText: Distant orange rock cliffs are seen through a forest along a sandy trail
images.title: Riggs Spring Loop Trail
images.caption: The Riggs Spring Loop Trail provides views of the cliffs and forest below Yovimpa Point

bodyText:
Riggs Spring Loop

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 8.8 miles (14.2 km)
Ascent:  2,503 feet (763 m)
Average time: 4-6 Hours

This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m).
Descending from the rim, this 8.8 mile (14.2 km) trail meanders through forests and raised promontories, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance. Gain a new perspective of the Grand Staircase by descending to its next stair--the Cretaceous sandstones of the Grey Cliffs. To preserve this experience, backcountry camping is permitted only in designated campsites. A backcountry permit must be obtained at the Visitor Center prior to any overnight trips. This trail is not as easily followed as developed trails within the Bryce Amphitheater.

Camping (Permits Available at Visitor Center)

There are 4 campsites on the 8.8 mile (14.2 km) Riggs Spring Loop Trail, which also can be accessed from here. You must obtain a permit to use these sites.

Under-the-Rim Trail

Access the Under-the-Rim Trail by following signs for the Bristlecone Loop Trail east toward Rainbow Point.

Backcountry Hiking and Camping

The Under-the-Rim Trail is approximately 22.9 miles (36.9 km) from Bryce Point to Rainbow Point. Connecting trails offer access from the park's Scenic Drive and intersect the Under-the-Rim Trail at Swamp Canyon, and Whiteman Bench. Agua Canyon Connector Trail **is closed** until further notice due to storm damage.

The Riggs Spring Loop is an 8.6 mile (13.9 km) hike beginning and ending at the Rainbow and Yovimpa Point parking lot at the south end of the Scenic Drive. Either the Yovimpa or Rainbow Point trailhead may be used to access this loop.

A backcountry hiking map with mileage is available at the Visitor Center. More information

Permits Required

A Backcountry Permit is required for all overnight stays in the backcountry. Permits may be purchased at the Visitor Center from 9 am - 12:30 pm and 1:30 pm to 6 pm. Backcountry campsites are limited to 6 people per regular site, and 15 people per group site.

No Fires Permitted

Though gas-powered cooking stoves are allowed, no open fires are allowed anywhere in the park outside of North and Sunset Campground's established fire rings.

Bears and Other Wildlife

Bryce Canyon is home to many animals including mountain lions, coyotes and black bears. Squirrels, snakes and other small animals may also be present near your campsite.
Due to the presence of black bears within Bryce Canyon National Park, the use of bear-resistant food canisters on overnight backcountry hikes is highly recommended. Bear-resistant canisters are available for loan, free of charge, at the Visitor Center.

Transportation

No park-provided transportation is provided south of Bryce Point. You can arrange a private shuttle using approved providers listed on our Commercial Tours and Services page.
audioDescription:
Yovimpa Pass and Riggs Spring Trailhead and wayside

A color photograph shows a landscape of red rock along the rim of the canyon. Caption reads: View from Yovimpa Point

A detailed map of the park runs along the left side of the panel and illustrates all overlooks, shuttle stops, picnic areas, and camping and hiking opportunities. A You are Here arrow points to Yovimpa Point, the southernmost end of the park.

Panel content describes backcountry rules, safety, trails and campsites in the vicinity.

Bryce Canyon's Backcountry

Bryce Canyon is best known for its hoodoos-bizarre pinnacles of rock left
standing by the forces of erosion. Hoodoos are best experienced from the park's day hiking trails. By contrast, our backcountry trails offer forests, meadows, some interesting geologic features, lots of solitude, but few hoodoos.




There are four backcountry Campsites in the area of Yovimpa Point:
Yovimpa Pass, Corral Hollow, Riggs Springs and Iron Spring
A color photograph for each of the four campgrounds shows a clearing in a forested area to set up camp.

title: Rim Trail Bryce Point Trailhead
listingDescription: This is the southern end of the 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail that begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point.

images.altText: Two hikers pause along a path to view a red rock landscape of badlands and spires at a cliff's edge
images.title: Rim Trail
images.caption: The Rim Trail provides easy to moderate walks along the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater.

bodyText:
The Rim Trail

Difficulty: Varies (Easy to Moderate)
Total Distance: 5.5 miles (8.9 km)
Ascent/Descent (South to North): 1,330 feet (405 m) / 1,825 feet (556 m)
Average time: 3-4 hours

The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point. The trail connects all viewpoints in the Bryce Amphitheater area and can be accessed at each of them.
Note that the section between here and Inspiration Point is closed in winter.

Recommended

The section between Sunrise and Sunset Points is 0.5 miles (0.8 km), paved and has only minor elevation changes; this portion is wheelchair accessible except in severe weather.
This section between Sunrise and Sunset Points is also the only section of the Rim Trail pets are allowed on; all pets must be on leash and owners must pick up after them. 
During shuttle season, hikers may use stops here, at Inspiration, Sunset, and Sunrise to complete one-way hikes. Fairyland Point has no shuttle service. The section from Bryce to Inspiration is closed in winter.

Distances and Elevation Change

Bryce Point to Inspiration Point: 1.5 miles (2.4 km) +556 feet / -702 feet
Inspiration Point to Sunset Point: 0.7 miles (1.1 km) +104 feet / -242 feet
Sunset Point to Sunrise Point: 0.5 miles (0.8 km) +82 feet / -65 feet
Sunrise Point to Fairyland Point: 2.8 miles (4.5 km) +182 feet / -399 feet
audioDescription: A compacted sediment trail begins here off of a paved walkway leading to Bryce Point. Steep cliffs exist along the righthand side of the path almost immediately, looking down upon a landscape of vibrant redrock limestone spires and forest.

From here, turn left to travel north to Sunset Point. Turn right to travel south to Bryce Point. Note that the section between here and Bryce Point is closed in winter.

Distances and Elevation Change

Bryce Point to Inspiration Point: 1.5 miles (2.4 km) +556 feet / -702 feet
Inspiration Point to Sunset Point: 0.7 miles (1.1 km) +104 feet / -242 feet

audioDescription: Paths lead north and south from here along the high cliffs of the plateau edge. The viewpoint at Inspiration Point consists of three overlooks that provide varied perspectives of the main amphitheater, which is an expansive bowl-like feature carved into the edge of this high plateau. The canyon is filled with thousands of irregularly eroded spires of rocks called hoodoos, each pinnacle and its surrounding cliff faces are layered with jagged striations of orange, white, gray and brown stone fading to soft rolling hills of forest in the distant valley. From here, visitors look toward the north to Sunset Point with its many rows of hoodoos and Sunrise Point set against the backdrop of Boat Mesa.

audioDescription: Paved sidewalks lead north, west, and south from Sunset Point. Sunset Point offers vistas of some of the most famous and breathtaking of Bryce Canyon's hoodoos. A railing with metal posts and chain-link fencing surrounds the overlook. The Navajo Loop Trail descends from Sunset Point. Water and restrooms are in the vicinity. Directly below the point and to the south, rising from the canyon floor, a web of spired hoodoos and fins are packed in tight formation. Vibrant red, oranges, and yellows of the lower half of the cliffs change to white toward the top of the plateau. Just below the overlook at the northern edge, a hoodoo named Thor's Hammer stands alone. Isolated from other hoodoos it stands a very tall spire with a wide base that narrows toward the top where it seems as if a large rock were placed at the tip, resembling the head of a hammer.

bodyText:
Rim Trail: Inspiration Point Orientation

Hikers can enjoy an easy 0.7-mile (1.2 km) walk north to Sunset Point above the Silent City, or a moderate 1.5-mi (2.4 km) hike south along steep cliffs to Bryce Point. When the shuttle is running, it can be used to enjoy one-way hikes between viewpoints as far north as Sunrise Point.

In winter the section of Rim Trail between Bryce and Inspiration points is closed.
audioDescription: The first provides details about the Rim Trail. A map illustrates that we are at the Inspiration point overlook and a graphic provides details about the trail: Length: 5.5 miles (8.9 km) from Bryce Point to Fairyland Point. Difficulty: Varies Total Ascent: 720 feet (219 m) Text Continues: Rim Trail: Inspiration Point Orientation Hikers can enjoy an easy 0.7-mile (1.2 km) walk north to Sunset Point above the Silent City, or a moderate 1.5-mi (2.4 km) hike south along steep cliffs to Bryce Point. When the shuttle is running, it can be used to enjoy one-way hikes between viewpoints as far north as Sunrise Point. In winter the section of Rim Trail between Bryce and Inspiration points is closed. A photograph along the bottom of the panel shows the view of the Bryce Amphitheater looking northeast to Sunset and Sunrise Points. Inspiration Point is popular for sunrises and sunsets. An inset photographs shows two people sitting along the edge of the Rim trail awaiting the sunrise at Inspiration Point.

title: Searching for Sustenance wayside

images.altText: A wayside exhibit giving insight to the people before us: Fremont, ancestral Puebloan, Paiute.
images.title: Searching for Sustenance
images.caption: People have been living in Bryce Canyon for over 10,000 years.

bodyText: People have been living in Bryce Canyon for over 10,000 years. Spearpoints and arrowheads, grinding stones, pottery shards, baskets, and oral histories of indigenous cultures—Paleo Indians, Fremont, Ancestral Puebloan—tell the story of their lives. Today, many tribes have traditional ties to this land, including Hopi, Ute, Zuni, and others. Of these, the Southern Paiute people live the closest to Bryce Canyon. They migrated seasonally building shelters, like wikiups, that provided protection from the sun, wind, and cold. Today they live in modern structures, but still move seasonally through their homelands to gather, hunt, fish, and maintain their connection to the land.
audioDescription: This panel along the Rim trail between Sunrise and Sunset points offers insight to the Fremont, ancestral Puebloan, and Paiute cultures. Title reads: Searching for Sustenance A color illustration of a group of American Indians taking part in various tasks necessary for daily life covers the panel. Tasks depicted include gathering edible berries and seeds, sitting beside dome shaped shelters, carrying vessels and working with animal skins. Captions further describe the lifeways: Edible berries, including manzanita, serviceberry, and chokecherry are gathered. Others, like Oregon grape, are used for medicine and dyes. Ricegrass and other grass seeds are being gathered in willow baskets. They are roasted, producing cereal grains. Ponderosa and other pines are used to construct the dome shaped wikiups, kahns, and other shelters. Rabbits, deer, mountain sheep, and other animals provide food and hides for clothing, tools, and crafts. Text Continues People have been living in Bryce Canyon for over 10,000 years. Spearpoints and arrowheads, grinding stones, pottery shards, baskets, and oral histories of indigenous cultures—Paleo Indians, Fremont, Ancestral Puebloan—tell the story of their lives. Today, many tribes have traditional ties to this land, including Hopi, Ute, Zuni, and others. Of these, the Southern Paiute people live the closest to Bryce Canyon. They migrated seasonally building shelters, like wikiups, that provided protection from the sun, wind, and cold. Today they live in modern structures, but still move seasonally through their homelands to gather, hunt, fish, and maintain their connection to the land.  An inset photograph highlights two Southern Paiute youths performing traditional ceremonies while an elder holds a drum. Caption reads: Southern Paiutes, like other tribes, still pass their traditional identity, language, and knowledge on to future generations.

title: Service Station wayside
listingDescription: After World War II, automobile sales surged, and thousands of eager tourists arrived to explore the park. To adapt to the change in visitation, the Utah Parks Company, a subsidiary of the Union Pacific Railroad, built this full-service Standard Oil station in 1947. Identical stations were also built nearby at Zion and the North Rim of Grand Canyon. The station's design was notable for being one of the first examples of the emerging Modern Movement architectural style.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit with information about the historic Service Station.
images.title: Fill 'Er Up
images.caption: The Utah Parks Company built this full-service Standard Oil station in 1947.

bodyText: After World War II, automobile sales surged, and thousands of eager tourists arrived to explore the park. To adapt to the change in visitation, the Utah Parks Company, a subsidiary of the Union Pacific Railroad, built this full-service Standard Oil station in 1947. Identical stations were also built nearby at Zion and the North Rim of Grand Canyon. The station's design was notable for being one of the first examples of the emerging Modern Movement architectural style in national parks, a departure from the Rustic Style of the 1920s, 30s, and early 40s. Elements of this style can be seen in the building's arcing stone wall, flat roof planes, and large windows. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1995.
audioDescription: Service Station Two exhibit panels here, across the parking lot, face the service station and describe its history and the impact car travel had on park visitation. The station was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1995. The First Panel titled: Fill ‘er Up shows a black and white photograph taken in 1938 of two men, gas station attendants, with short hair, wearing white pants and shirts. They face us, posing in the island beside the gas pumps. Text continues: After World War II, automobile sales surged, and thousands of eager tourists arrived to explore the park. To adapt to the change in visitation, the Utah Parks Company, a subsidiary of the Union Pacific Railroad, built this full-service Standard Oil station in 1947. Identical stations were also built nearby at Zion and the North Rim of Grand Canyon. The station's design was notable for being one of the first examples of the emerging Modern Movement architectural style in national parks, a departure from the Rustic Style of the 1920s, 30s, and early 40s. Elements of this style can be seen in the building's arcing stone wall, flat roof planes, and large windows. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1995. Caption reads: In 1972, the Union Pacific turned this station and other buildings over to the National Park Service. By 1988, the growing number of local service stations made this one obsolete and it closed. Description of the station follows: The service station is located adjacent to the park road midway between Bryce Canyon Lodge and Sunrise Point. This one-story, irregularly shaped building with five interior rooms and auto repair shop and was designed in a modern style with a wide, flat rooftop that projects out from the main entrance to provide a canopy over the gas pump island. The canopy is held up by two steel posts. The entire front face of the service station has a large expanse of floor to ceiling glass windows with white trim and a sided in pine board paneling and a single overhead sliding garage door that is also entirely made of glass windows. The dominant feature is a coursed sandstone wall that curves around the back of the building. The wall, constructed of rough-cut local sandstone and concrete mortar forms the back of the building and extends out beyond the building walls and rises above the roofline to form a backdrop. Behind the stone wall is a hillslope covered in native Ponderosa pine. Between the road and the service station is an oval shaped island of grasses and a solitary Pondarosa Pine surrounded by a raised stone retaining wall.

bodyText:
Shuttle Stop located on the northbound side of the main road near Sunset Campground. Park shuttles run mid-April through mid-October.

Now You Can Track the Shuttle!

Buses typically come every 15 minutes from 8 am to 6 pm in Spring and Fall and until 8 pm in summer, but with the new Bryce Canyon Shuttle Tracker you can time your next ride to the minute.

Riding the Free Bryce Canyon Shuttle

Bryce Canyon is one of many busy national parks that has a mass transit system to minimize vehicle congestion and the resulting impacts that jeopardize the very things we all treasure about national parks. With the exception of vehicles measuring 23 feet (7 m) or longer, which are restricted from the Bryce Amphitheater during shuttle hours, riding the shuttle is not mandatory. However, by riding our buses you will support our efforts to keep our parking lots from growing any larger, to keep our pure air as clean as possible, and to provide enough room in our little park for everyone to experience the magic of Bryce Canyon.

The Bryce Amphitheater Shuttle runs regularly on 15 minute intervals from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. with extended hours to 8 p.m. in summer, and brings visitors to areas of interest, viewpoints, and trailheads within the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park. The shuttle is free with park admission.

How to use the Shuttle

There is no extra fee to use the shuttle system. Paying your $35 entrance fee to Bryce Canyon entitles you and your vehicle's occupants to unlimited use of the Bryce Canyon Shuttle buses.

Annual Passes waive the entrance fee to not only this park but all other National Park Service Areas and other Federal lands that may have fees, across the entire country. If you do not already have one of these annual passes they can be purchased at the entrance to the park.

If you are not staying overnight inside the park at either the Bryce Canyon Lodge or North or Sunset Campground, we strongly encourage you to leave your vehicle outside the park. Please park and board the shuttle at the Shuttle Station (near Ruby's Inn, on the left side of the road before entering the park) or at Ruby's Campground. 

Read more about the Shuttle

A crosswalk leading west to the southbound Sunset Campground shuttle stop is located just north along the road.

audioDescription:
Sunset Point Shuttle Stop (2 panels)
Bryce Canyon Shuttle

A two-sided upright exhibit panel orients visitors to the details of riding the park shuttle and highlights features of interest that can be found at each stop. The panel is framed in rusted metal with a decorative cut out of hoodoos across the top. There is an open-air shelter with benches at each stop.

One side of the panel is a full color map marking each shuttle stop along the first three miles of road in the park known popularly as the Bryce Amphitheater.
Text reads:
Leave the car behind in fee Bryce Canyon on the shuttle. The shuttle brings people into the park from Ruby's Inn and stops at the Bryce Canyon visitor center and main amphitheater overlooks and trailheads. It also goes to campgrounds, Bryce Canyon lodge and the general store. The shuttle runs summers only please see bulletin board for shuttle schedules.

The Bryce Canyon shuttle make stops at the following locations: Ruby's Inn, Ruby's campground, Visitor Center, North campground trailer drop off shuttle parking area, Sunset campground, Bryce Point, Inspiration Point, Sunset Point, the Lodge, Sunrise Point and General Store. The route duration is 50 minutes and the bus interval is every 10 to 15 minutes. There are hiking trails, scenic overlooks and ranger programs available.

Facilities and services here are: hiking trails and scenic overlooks, ranger programs, drinking water, picnic areas and restrooms.

Sunset Point Shuttle Stop
The other side of the orientation panel highlights features of interest and facts about the park. Photographs of landscapes and animals accompany text.
Panel title: Sunset Point
text reads:

The Navajo loop trail is short but steep the one point three-mile loop is one of Bryce canyon's most popular routes. Wall Street is the narrow Gorge at the end of the switchbacks marked by 2 Douglas firs. Peekaboo loop and Queens garden trail joined the Navajo loop trail just after Wall Street.
The rim trail runs along the perimeter of the Bryce Amphitheatre from sunrise point to Bryce point the leg of this trail stretching from here to sunrise point is the easiest stroll in the park and is accessible to everyone.

Three photographs of deep orange and red rock landscapes of hoodoos against blue sky accompany the text. Captions read: Thor's hammer, sunrise through hoodoos, and Wall Street.

A side bar on the left side of the panel has a close-up photograph of the red spires of the canyon text reads: did you know?
Bryce canyon's magic is found in its colorful hoodoos. These stone columns are carved by ice and rain. For about 200 days a year, snow and ice will melt in the afternoon and freeze at night. When the water freezes, it expands and pushes the rocks apart creating the different hoodoos and windows that can be found in the amphitheaters.

Along the bottom of the panel a series of 4 photographs a plants and animals found here first a bird, the Violet green swallow; then a plant, the Oregon grape; the Douglas fir tree; and the mule deer.

audioDescription: Sunrise Point Shuttle Stop (2 panels) 525 words Bryce Canyon Shuttle A two-sided upright exhibit panel orients visitors to the details of riding the park shuttle and highlights features of interest that can be found at each stop. The panel is framed in rusted metal with a decorative cut out of the hoodoos and mountains of the canyon across the top. There is an open-air shelter with benches at each stop. One side of the panel is a full color map marking each shuttle stop along the first three miles of road in the park popularly known as Bryce Amphitheater. Text reads: Leave the car behind and see Bryce Canyon on the shuttle. The shuttle brings people into the park from Ruby's Inn and stops at the Bryce Canyon visitor center and main amphitheater overlooks and trailheads. It also goes to campgrounds, Bryce Canyon lodge and the general store. The shuttle runs summers only please see bulletin board for shuttle schedules. The Bryce Canyon shuttle make stops at the following locations Ruby's Inn, Ruby's campground, visitor center, North campground trailer drop off, shuttle parking area, sunset campground, Bryce point, inspiration point sunset point, the lodge, sunrise point, and general store. The route duration is 50 minutes and the bus interval is every 10 to 15 minutes. Facilities and services here are: Hiking trails, scenic overlook, restrooms, drinking water, telephone, Ranger programs, picnic area, camping, dump station, showers, grocery, laundry, snack bar. The other side of the orientation panel highlights features of interest and facts about the park. Photographs of landscapes and animals accompany text. Panel title: Sunrise Point Text reads: Queens garden trail slopes under the mellow, stony gaze of hundreds of hoodoos. Boat Mesa, the sinking ship and the Aquarius plateau can be seen along the way. For a longer hike take the connecting trail at the bottom of the Canyon to join the Navajo loop trail the hike to see the royal who do known as Queen Victoria is less than 2 miles round trip, and descends 320 feet. Please remember that higher elevations make even the easiest of trails more difficult. 4 color photographs accompany the text; exposed roots of a limber pine tree, the Queen Victoria Hoodoo the Queen's garden trail and a landscape view of Queens garden. A side bar on the left side of the panel has a cut away diagram of the many different types and colors of rock cliffs that form the layers of the canyon. Text reads: Did you know? Bryce Canyon is the top step of the grand staircase. Aptly named, this cascading series of cliffs stretches like descending stairs from Bryce Canyon to Zion to the North rim of the Grand Canyon. The name for each set of cliffs in the grand staircase describes its color: pink cliffs, great cliffs, white cliffs, Vermilion cliffs and chocolate cliffs. In its multitude of layers the grand staircase tells the story of over 200 million years of changing landscapes. Along the bottom of the panel a series of 4 photographs of plants and animals found here first a small mammal: The Utah Prairie dog; then a wild Turkey; a plant: the greenleaf manzanita; and a pinyon pine tree.

bodyText:
Shuttle stop located at the Best Western Plus Grand Hotel. Purchase a digital pass before you arrive and simply show it to the driver when you board.

Now You Can Track the Shuttle!

Buses typically come every 15 minutes from 8 am to 6 pm in Spring and Fall and until 8 pm in summer, but with the new Bryce Canyon Shuttle Tracker you can time your next ride to the minute.

Riding the Free Bryce Canyon Shuttle

Bryce Canyon is one of many busy national parks that has a mass transit system to minimize vehicle congestion and the resulting impacts that jeopardize the very things we all treasure about national parks. With the exception of vehicles measuring 23 feet (7 m) or longer, which are restricted from the Bryce Amphitheater during shuttle hours, riding the shuttle is not mandatory. However, by riding our buses you will support our efforts to keep our parking lots from growing any larger, to keep our pure air as clean as possible, and to provide enough room in our little park for everyone to experience the magic of Bryce Canyon.

The Bryce Amphitheater Shuttle runs regularly on 15 minute intervals from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. with extended hours to 8 p.m. in summer, and brings visitors to areas of interest, viewpoints, and trailheads within the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park. The shuttle is free with park admission.

How to use the Shuttle

There is no extra fee to use the shuttle system. Paying your $35 entrance fee to Bryce Canyon entitles you and your vehicle's occupants to unlimited use of the Bryce Canyon Shuttle buses.

Annual Passes waive the entrance fee to not only this park but all other National Park Service Areas and other Federal lands that may have fees, across the entire country. If you do not already have one of these annual passes they can be purchased at the entrance to the park.

If you are not staying overnight inside the park at either the Bryce Canyon Lodge or North or Sunset Campground, we strongly encourage you to leave your vehicle outside the park. Please park and board the shuttle at the Shuttle Station (near Ruby's Inn, on the left side of the road before entering the park) or at Ruby's Campground. 

Read more about the Shuttle

audioDescription:
The Bryce Canyon Shuttle

A two-sided upright exhibit panel orients visitors to the details of riding the park shuttle and highlights features of interest that can be found at each stop.

The panel is framed in rusted metal with a decorative cut out of hoodoos the top. There is an open-air shelter with benches at each stop.

One side of the panel is a full color map marking each shuttle stop along the 18 miles of road in the park.

Text reads:
Leave the car behind in fee Bryce Canyon on the shuttle. The shuttle brings people into the park from Ruby's Inn and stops at the Bryce Canyon visitor center and main amphitheater overlooks and trailheads. It also goes to campgrounds, Bryce Canyon lodge and the general store. The shuttle runs summers only please see bulletin board for shuttle schedules.

The Bryce Canyon shuttle make stops at the following locations: Ruby's Inn, Ruby's campground, Visitor Center, North campground trailer drop off shuttle parking area, Sunset campground, Bryce Point, Inspiration Point, Sunset Point, the Lodge, Sunrise Point and General Store. The route duration is 50 minutes and the bus interval is every 10 to 15 minutes. There are hiking trails, scenic overlooks and ranger programs available.

The other side of the orientation panel highlights features of interest and facts about the park. Photographs of landscapes and animals accompany text.

Panel title: Sunset Campground Shuttle Stop
Black and white photographs show what camping was like in the past with a pitched canvas tent, a now antique car and then in contrast a color photograph shows modern day camping with a motor home.

Text reads: Camping is a timeless tradition in Bryce Canyon and national parks throughout the country. Historically campsites allowed Americans to stay in the park at little expense, strengthening the love affair between visitor and the park. It continues to do so today. Another color photograph of a trailhead path is captioned: trail to sunset point.
Text reads: The short trail located across the road at the crosswalk, connects sunset campground to the beauty of sunset point. This overlook offers views down into the natural artistry of hoodoos that comprise the Bryce amphitheater.

A side bar along the right side of the panel shows an image of a small mammal, a prairie dog on its hind legs. Text reads:
Bryce Canyon has its own population of Utah Prairie dogs. An endangered species this Colony was introduced here to help with the recovery of the animals these popular creatures can be seen from a safe distance in the Meadow near sunset campground.

Along the bottom of the panel a series of 4 photographs of plants and animals found here: first a gray and black bird with a pointed black bill, the Clark's nutcracker; then the ponderosa pine tree; a large gray and blue bird with a crest on its head: the Steller's Jay; and a plant with soft yellow flowers: antelope bitterbrush.

audioDescription:

A two-sided upright panel orients visitors to the details of riding the park shuttle and highlights features of interest that can be found at each stop. The panel is framed in rusted metal with a decorative cut out of hoodoos across the top. There is an open-air shelter with benches at each stop.

Text reads:
Leave the car behind in fee Bryce Canyon on the shuttle. The shuttle brings people into the park from ruby's Inn and stops at the Bryce Canyon visitor center and main amphitheater overlooks and trailheads. It also goes to campgrounds, Bryce Canyon lodge and the general store. The shuttle runs summers only please see bulletin board for shuttle schedules.

The route duration is 50 minutes and the bus interval is every 10 to 15 minutes. there are hiking trails and scenic overlooks along the way.

The other side of the Shuttle Stop orientation panel highlights several features of interest and facts about the park. Photographs of landscapes and animals accompany text.

Panel title: Bryce Point
Text reads: Bryce point overlook offers fantastic views of hoodoos and grottoes it is also a great place to enjoy the morning sunrise. The overlook is a short walk from the parking lot. The rim trail begins here and continues to fairy land photographs of the landscape captioned silent city and peekaboo loop trail are shown.

Text continues:
The whimsical wall of windows is one of many features found along the 5.5 mile peekaboo loop trail.

Two more photographs of landscape features: the wall of windows and the hat shop show 2 hoodoos with large rocks on top as if hats.

Text continues:
The under the rim trail extends 23 miles and is a launching point for many backpacking routes. Take this trail to reach the hat shop. 2.3 miles from the Bryce Point trail head.

Along the bottom of the panel a series of four photographs of plants and animals found here: first the Golden mantled ground squirrel; next, another squirrel like animal: the Uinta chipmunk; then a bird, the California Condor; and the limber pine tree.

Text reads:
Leave the car behind in fee Bryce Canyon on the shuttle. The shuttle brings people into the park from Ruby's Inn and stops at the Bryce Canyon visitor center and main amphitheater overlooks and trailheads. It also goes to campgrounds, Bryce Canyon lodge and the general store.

The shuttle runs summers only please see bulletin board for shuttle schedules. The other side of the orientation panel highlights features of interest and facts about the park. Photographs of landscapes and animals accompany text.

Panel two: Panel title: Inspiration Point
Text reads: Inspiration point rewards observers with views of indescribable beauty. Explore all three overlooks to discover new vistas. The higher points allow a more commanding view of the Canyon.

There are 3 photographs of the canyon landscape here: the first is captioned silent city from inspiration point, another shows the hoodoo-filled view from inspiration point and the third depicts Bryce Canyon under snow. Text continues: a wide spectrum of color and stone can be seen along the rim trail.

From inspiration point to sunset point the 0.7 miles segment offers glimpses of silent city the cathedral, the wall of windows and Wall Street

A sidebar exhibit panel on the right reads did you know and shows a photograph of a coyote. Text reads: an elderly Paiute named Indian Dick describes how Bryce Canyon was formed before there were any Indians. The legend people lived in this place. They were of many kinds birds, animals, lizards, and such things but they had the power to make themselves look like people for some reason. The legend people were bad so coyote turned them all into rocks you can see them in that place now all turned into rocks some standing in rows some sitting down some holding on to others you can see their faces with paint on them just as they were before they became rocks.

Along the bottom of the panel a series of 4 photographs a plants and animals found here first a mountain short horned lizard; then a large black bird, the common Raven; then a yellow daisy-like flower, broom groundsel; and the bristlecone pine tree.

title: Solar Voltaic Arrays

images.altText: Two solar panels stand in field surrounded by brown wooden fence
images.title: Bryce Canyon Solar Panels
images.caption: The two solarvoltaic arrays are located just beside the Visitor Center

bodyText:
How it Works

The Bryce Canyon Solar Array consists of two dual-axis trackers that perfectly follow our Sun throughout each day during every season of the year. Such telescope-like precision is required because unlike regular photovoltaic panels, Concentrating PhotoVoltaic (CPV) technology does not generate electricity from ambient light. For the Fresnel lens to concentrate sunlight and for the tiny triple-junction chips to convert it to electricity, the sun alignment has to be within 1-2 degrees. 

When installed in sunny locations, CPV outperforms all other kinds of solar energy, both in sunlight conversion efficiency and energy density (kilowatts / acre).  Operating at 140kW per hour and peaking at 150kW, this array generates more energy than can be easily stored in batteries, so instead, excess energy is returned to the grid.  On a sunny day, the array generates more than twice the energy the Bryce Canyon Visitor Center uses, providing us with an energy credit that can then be reclaimed at night or on cloudy days.  

The Photovoltaic Cell

Each tracker consists of 5,040 individual solar collection cells.  Sunlight enters each cell through a Fresnel lens, (commonly used in lighthouses to focus light into a beam) which concentrates sunlight through a reflecting chamber on to a tiny triple junction photovoltaic chip. 

Because all photovoltaics perform better at cooler temperatures, the chip itself is mounted on a large aluminum heat-sink (similar to those used to cool computer processors) with blades that extend out of the cell, on the shaded size of the unit, where air circulation aids in further 

Maximizing Solar Energy

Only half of our Sun’s energy reaches Earth’s surface. The narrow range known as optical light is what the human eye-brain combination uses. Through photosynthesis, plants convert 2-4% of solar energy into sugars. The best silicon solar panels are about 18% efficient. Concentrating PhotoVoltaics (CPV) technology focuses light onto triple-stacked photocells of different alloys. Each layer in the stack collects sunlight from a different part of the spectrum, that when added together, converts 34% of our Sun’s transmitted energy into electricity.

Other Facts

  • When wind speeds exceed 35 mph, each tracker’s anemometer instructs it to tilt back to the horizontal wind stow position where they can survive winds speeds up to 100 mph. 

  • A clock drive allows the trackers to track our Sun even when cloudy. A sun-tracker in the upper center of each tracker adds precision when our Sun is out.

  • A pyrheliometer independently measures sunlight intensity and our Sun’s precise position in the sky to improve efficiency.
audioDescription: Down a sidewalk that runs from the main parking lot to the left of the entrance to the visitor center are two huge flat rectangular Solar Arrays (solar panels) 70’longx53’high, mounted up off the ground on tall pedestals. Beside the panels and intersecting the sidewalk to the visitor center is trailhead access to a five-mile shared use path for walkers and bikers.

title: Steps Through Time wayside
listingDescription: The first dinosaurs, two mass extinctions, the breaking apart of the supercontinent Pangea—these are just a few of the stories contained in the more than 2 miles (3.2 km) of rocks beneath your feet, and the view stretching over 100 miles (160 km) south.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit showing how Bryce Canyon is at the top of the Grand Staircase.
images.title: Steps Through Time
images.caption: Bryce Canyon's Pink Cliffs are at the top of the Grand Staircase.

bodyText:
The first dinosaurs, two mass extinctions, the breaking apart of the supercontinent Pangea—these are just a few of the stories contained in the more than 2 miles (3.2 km) of rocks beneath your feet, and the view stretching over 100 miles (160 km) south.

Uplifted and exposed over the last 20+ million years, the landscape between the Grand Canyon and Bryce Canyon is a unique geological province known as the Grand Staircase. Named for its series of colorful cliffs, these exposed layers of sedimentary rock and their fossils preserve one of the most complete records of changing life and environments over the last 250 million years on Earth.
audioDescription: There are two exhibits here at Yovimpa Point to describe how the park is located at the top of the Grand Staircase, to identify by name the colorful cliffs of interest in the distance and to explain the monitoring and importance of good air quality. A path runs adjacent to the plateaus edge and is enclosed with a horizontal log railing. A panoramic photograph shows a view to the south and includes a large portion of the sequence of rock layers called the Grand Staircase: step-like cliffs, each step or rock layer is made from hard, colorful sedimentary rocks beginning at the bottom with Chocolate colored Mudstone, Vermilion mudstone and sandstone, White sandstone, Grey Shales and Pink Limestones. From left to right, the colorful cliffs and points of interest in the distance are labeled on the panoramic photograph: Navajo Mountain, Pink Cliffs 50 mya: a large, fresh-water lake, Grey Cliffs 90 mya: a large inland sea, Molly’s Nipple (White Cliffs), White Cliffs 190 mya: vast dune-filled desert, Vermilion Cliffs 195 mya: desert with shallow streams, Chocolate Cliffs 250 mya: swampy, muddy floodplain (visible). The canyon stretches on for miles and below, the valleys are covered in a dense green carpet of forest with only the plateau edges and steep cliffs of pink and orange rock void of any vegetation. Title and text continue: Steps Through Time The first dinosaurs, two mass extinctions, the breaking apart of the supercontinent Pangea—these are just a few of the stories contained in the more than 2 miles (3.2 km) of rocks beneath your feet, and the view stretching over 100 miles (160 km) south. Uplifted and exposed over the last 20+ million years, the landscape between the Grand Canyon and Bryce Canyon is a unique geological province known as the Grand Staircase. Named for its series of colorful cliffs, these exposed layers of sedimentary rock and their fossils preserve one of the most complete records of changing life and environments over the last 250 million years on Earth. A small inset diagram in cross section of the Grand Staircase shows the park among the colored layers of exposed cliffs to the north, Zion to the west and the Grand Canyon in the distance to the south. Caption reads: Bryce Canyon's Pink Cliffs are at the top of the Staircase, and each step leads down into the past. The oldest layers of Bryce Canyon are younger than the layers of Zion, and the oldest layers of Zion are the youngest of the Grand Canyon.
