images.title: Sunrise Motel
images.caption: The Sunrise Motel is one of two motel units associated with the Bryce Canyon Lodge.

bodyText:
The Sunrise and Sunset Hotels are two-story structures located to the south and north of the main lodge building. These buildings provide accessible, rustic-themed lodging within minutes of the rim of the iconic Bryce Amphitheater. 

Reservations
audioDescription: Sunrise Hotel 119 words Sunrise Hotel is located to the northeast of the lodge and sunset motel to the southwest, both are similar in design and appearance. Each two-story rectangular building was built to portray the rustic design of the original lodge by using log and stone. Exterior woodwork is painted dark brown or is a natural light brown log with clear stain. There are stone entrances, rustic porches and balconies of large log framework and log railings. Gabled roofs provide a roofed and shaded upper balcony. The shingles are laid horizontally, without the wavy patterns of earlier days. Each hotel is set into the natural landscape and surrounded by ponderosa pine and low growing native shrubs. Concrete walkways surround each building.

title: Sunrise Point
listingDescription: Sunrise Point is the northernmost of the four major viewpoints that overlook the iconic Bryce Amphitheater. Though this point along with Sunset Point was named to entice early Lodge visitors to easily accessible points along the rim at both times of day, this view is equally spectacular at daybreak and day's end.

images.altText: A tree with exposed roots stands at the edge of a landscape of red and white rock spires
images.title: Sunrise Point
images.caption: Sunrise Point provides views like this one beside "Stilts" of the Bryce Amphitheater from the North

bodyText:
Sunrise Point is the northernmost of the four major viewpoints that overlook the iconic Bryce Amphitheater. Though this point along with Sunset Point was named to entice early Lodge visitors to easily accessible points along the rim at both times of day, this view is equally spectacular at daybreak and day's end. At an elevation of 8,100 feet (2,469 m), Sunrise Point is just slightly higher than the Rim Trail and the ponderosa forest to the west. This provides one with a 360 degree view, making it a great choice for stargazers, and those hoping to see the sun's final light along the western horizon. The view of the rock formations (hoodoos) within the Bryce Amphitheater is exceptional as well. Here one can clearly see the full process of hoodoo formation as the plateau rim erodes back exposing walls or fins of layered rock, which are then broken by frost-wedging with windows (arches) that expand to eventually form the isolated columns of stone known as hoodoos. Further east, the eye traces to see these hoodoos' final state: colorful badlands of sediment spotted with vegetation, including bristlecone pines. The popular Queen's Garden trail provides an unforgettable journey down a ridgeline that provides views of every stage of this process.

Trails

The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail connects this view to Sunrise and Fairyland Points further north and Inspiration and Bryce Points further south. The most popular section is the 0.5 mile (0.8 km) section between here and Sunrise Point. This section is paved (and therefore permits leashed pets) and has minimal elevation changes. The Queen's Garden Trail also descends from this viewpoint area.

Landscape Features

To the Northeast

See the flat-topped feature of Boat Mesa and the angled slope of Sinking Ship set against the stark Pink Cliffs of the Table Cliff Plateau 17.5 miles (28 km) distant. The roughly 30 degree slope of Sinking Ship is evidence of the Paunsaugunt fault line, which travels north-south roughly along the eastern edge of the park. This fault, along with large fields of volcanic rock north of the park, were created as part of the tectonic events that elevated the Colorado Plateau region to its present day elevations and later produced the Basin and Range region to the west. The fault is a normal fault, which means that it was formed by extension--the ground you're standing upon moving down and away from the opposite side of the valley. This movement accounts for the 2,000 foot (610 m) difference in elevation between the Bryce Amphitheater and the Table Cliff plateau, despite these being formed of the same rock layer. Sinking Ship is slightly caught upon this fault, explaining its tilted appearance. Though once a site of intense movement, little activity has been recorded along the fault in the last 9 million years.

To the East

The large crown-shaped feature in the middle of the Bryce Amphitheater is known as Bristlecone Point. If you have some binoculars, you may be able to see their scraggly forms upon the white layers of the Claron formation capping Bristlecone Point. You can see that between here and Bristlecone Point is a series of colorful badlands that continue to the north, but steeply drop off into more forested areas to the south. One can see this as a north/south dividing line within the Bryce Amphitheater, where areas south have been eroded more deeply and undercut cliffs to the south (a trend that increases the further south in the park you travel), while erosion has been gentler and less dramatic further north. Beyond Bristlecone Point is the broad Paria Valley, which has been formed over the last 6 million years by the Paria River. The Paria River ultimately joins the Colorado River not too far from Navajo Mountain, visible on the southeastern horizon.

To the South

To the south, one can also see Sunset, Inspiration, and Bryce Points along the forested rim of the Paunsagunt Plateau. If you have an especially good eye (and know what you're looking for) you can spot Thor's Hammer along the Two Bridges side of the Navajo Loop below Sunset Point.

Nature

The Limber Pine at Sunrise Point (known as "Stilts"), roots exposed by erosion of the rim, serves as a reminder of the resilience and ability of life to adapt to adverse conditions, and also of the rapidity with which the scene before us is disappearing. Geologists have calculated that the rim of the canyon is eroding at a rate of one to four feet every century and that in approximately three million years, Bryce Canyon will be gone forever. The hoodoos of Bryce Canyon's main amphitheater appear as a snapshot in the rapid process of erosion on the Paunsaugunt Plateau. This rapidly eroding land creates a harsh environment for any living thing, and like this limber pine, all creatures which live here, from people to animals to plants, must adapt to the conditions in order to survive.
audioDescription: Ponderosa pine line the rim of the canyon here. To the northeast is Boat Mesa and the Sinking Ship formation set against the stark Pink Cliffs of the Table Cliff Plateau. Below the plateau’s rim, a mass of orange hoodoos and stonewalls are capped with a thick layer of resistant white limestone. At the far edge of the overlook stands one small, lone Limber Pine tree. It clings to the very edge of the eroding cliff; its tangled roots are exposed above ground and curve like legs as if it is standing or walking.

title: Sunset Point
listingDescription: Sunset Point offers vistas of some of the most famous and breathtaking of Bryce Canyon's hoodoos. Nowhere are the colors of Bryce Canyon's rock better displayed than from Sunset Point.

images.altText: Red and white rock fins stand among distant spires and forested landscape
images.title: Sunset Point
images.caption: Sunset Point provides views of narrow fins of rock and distant hoodoos within the Bryce Amphitheater

bodyText:
Sunset Point offers vistas of some of the most famous and breathtaking of Bryce Canyon's hoodoos. Few places are the colors of Bryce Canyon's rock better displayed than from Sunset Point. Called the Claron Formation, this unique rock is primarily composed of limestone deposited approximately 50 million years ago in a large freshwater lake, known to geologists as Lake Claron. Iron oxide minerals supply the vibrant red, oranges, and yellows of the lower half of the cliffs which geologists call the Pink Member. As its geologic names suggest, here too patches of pink and purple caused by manganese oxides add to the rainbow of color. The change from orange to white marks the beginning of the Upper Member. This section of limestone is purer; its lack of color is caused by the absence of mineral impurities.

Trails

The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail connects this view to Sunrise and Fairyland Points further north and Inspiration and Bryce Points further south. The most popular section is the 0.5 mile (0.8 km) section between here and Sunrise Point. This section is paved (and therefore permits leashed pets) and has minimal elevation changes. The Navajo Loop Trail also descends from this viewpoint area.

Landscape Features

To the North

A 0.5 mile (0.8 km) walk away, Sunrise Point rises gently along the rim, and Boat Mesa extends beyond the ridgeline of the Queen's Garden Trail's gentle descent from it.

To the East

The horizon is graced with the grandeur of the Table Cliff plateau, whose notched southern end (known as Powell Point) stands 13 miles distant and 2,000 ft (607 m) above you. Further off to the south, the rounded dome of Navajo Mountain rises 80 miles distant. Within the boundary of the park, the tilted layers of Sinking Ship reveal the location of the Paunsaugunt fault. See the Geology section for more information. Nearly directly below the viewpoint, the park's most famous hoodoo, Thor's Hammer stands. It is perhaps best seen along the Two Bridges side of the Navajo Loop. To the south, the rim rises toward Inspiration and Bryce Points. Below stands the fantastic maze of the Silent City, into which the Navajo Loop descends. Nowhere are the colors of Bryce Canyon's rock better displayed than from Sunset Point. Called the Claron Formation, this unique rock is primarily composed of limestone deposited approximately 50 million years ago in a large freshwater lake, known to geologists as Lake Claron. Iron oxide minerals supply the vibrant red, oranges, and yellows of the lower half of the cliffs which geologists call the Pink Member. As its geologic names suggest, here too patches of pink and purple caused by manganese oxides add to the rainbow of color. The change from orange to white marks the beginning of the Upper Member. This section of limestone is purer; its lack of color is caused by the absence of mineral impurities.
audioDescription:
Sunset Point and Sunset Point wayside 347 words

Sunset Point offers vistas of some of the most famous and breathtaking of Bryce Canyon's hoodoos. A railing with metal posts and chain-link fencing surrounds the overlook. The Navajo Loop Trail descends from Sunset Point. Water and restrooms are in the vicinity.

Directly below the point and to the south, rising from the canyon floor, a web of spired hoodoos and fins are packed in tight formation. Vibrant red, oranges, and yellows of the lower half of the cliffs change to white toward the top of the plateau. Just below the overlook at the northern edge, a hoodoo named Thor's Hammer stands alone. Isolated from other hoodoos it stands a very tall spire with a wide base that narrows toward the top where it seems as if a large rock were placed at the tip, resembling the head of a hammer.

A panel at the overlook reads:
Sunset Point.
At the top of the panel a watercolor illustration labels points of interest in the distant landscape. From left to right: boat Mesa is 2 miles away sinking ship is 3 miles in the distance and the Aquarius plateau is 15 miles in the distance. Next the Canaan Mountain 21 miles, and far right, Kaiparewits Plateau 45 miles and Navajo Mountain 82 miles away.

A color photograph below the illustration shows Sunset Point in winter. The hoodoo spires in the foreground are tipped with snow and the distant mesas and plateaus are snow-covered with only the greens of pine trees dotting the white landscape. Caption reads: water, ice and snow continue to carve the formations at Bryce Canyon.

Another photograph shows clusters of icicles hanging from the underside of the red cliffs. A quote by Peter Farb from the Face of North America, 1963 is below the photograph, it reads:
"...In this thirsty land, water has been the prime creator of scenery. Water formed these sedimentary rocks under ancient seas, and water sculpted them as they rose. Water carved the buttes and mesas, chiseled Bryce Canyon into every shape known."

title: Survivors wayside
listingDescription: The twisted, weathered branches of Great Basin bristlecone pines attest to their longevity and the harsh environment—dry soil, cold temperatures, high winds—under which they grow. These trees are survivors. This species adapts to extreme conditions, entering a dormant state that can last for years during drought. The slow growth rate creates a dense wood resistant to parasites and rotting. Sections of a tree may die, but sprawling roots channel water to living limbs.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit explaining how the Bristlecone pine thrives in harsh environments.
images.title: Survivors
images.caption: The Bristlecone gets its name from the sharp, claw-like bristles on its cones.

bodyText: The twisted, weathered branches of Great Basin bristlecone pines attest to their longevity and the harsh environment—dry soil, cold temperatures, high winds—under which they grow. These trees are survivors. This species adapts to extreme conditions, entering a dormant state that can last for years during drought. The slow growth rate creates a dense wood resistant to parasites and rotting. Sections of a tree may die, but sprawling roots channel water to living limbs. While the oldest known living bristlecone pine is over 5,000 years old, Bryce Canyon's oldest bristlecone pines are estimated to be around 1,600 years old. This shorter lifespan is partly due to high rates of erosion, which expose and dry their shallow roots. Help protect these special trees by always staying on the main trail.
audioDescription: A panel, a tactile pinecone and two botanical ID signs are here at the overlook along the Bristlecone Trail to explain how the Bristlecone pine tree thrives in harsh environments, and to provide identifying information about the Limber Pine and Bristlecone Pine trees. A photograph of the twisted and weathered branches of a Bristlecone Pine against a backdrop of the canyon below fills the scene. A close-up image of the green cone highlights that it is covered in brownish red “bristles” or pointed bumps. Feel the bronze tactile of the pinecone. Caption reads: The tree gets its name from the sharp, claw-like bristles on its cones. Title and text read: Survivors The twisted, weathered branches of Great Basin bristlecone pines attest to their longevity and the harsh environment—dry soil, cold temperatures, high winds—under which they grow. These trees are survivors. This species adapts to extreme conditions, entering a dormant state that can last for years during drought. The slow growth rate creates a dense wood resistant to parasites and rotting. Sections of a tree may die, but sprawling roots channel water to living limbs. While the oldest known living bristlecone pine is over 5,000 years old, Bryce Canyon's oldest bristlecone pines are estimated to be around 1,600 years old. This shorter lifespan is partly due to high rates of erosion, which expose and dry their shallow roots. Help protect these special trees by always staying on the main trail.

title: Swamp Canyon
listingDescription: Swamp Canyon completes the transition from the hoodoo-filled Bryce Amphitheater to the steep cliffs and buttes that characterize the scenic drive and southern end of the park.

images.altText: Forested canyon with tall bright orange limestone cliffs towering above
images.title: Swamp Canyon
images.caption: Swamp Canyon marks a transition from hoodoo-filled amphitheaters to more forested backcountry

bodyText:
Swamp Canyon begins a transition from the hoodoo-filled Bryce Amphitheater to the steep cliffs and buttes that characterize the scenic drive and southern end of the park. Many people assume that Swamp Canyon must be a misnomer. Although it might be the last place on Earth you would expect to find an alligator, compared to the rest of the park it is a virtual wetland. Here, below the rim, two tiny creeks and a spring provide enough water to sustain more lush vegetation like grasses and willows. This canyon remains wet enough year-around that it is also home to tiger salamanders and wild iris. Bird watchers enjoy hiking the Swamp Canyon Loop Trail as it traverses four distinctly different habitats offering the chance to see a wide diversity of songbirds.

Trails

The moderately strenuous 4.0 mi/6.4 km Swamp Canyon Loop begins at the north end of the parking lot. The trail descends 647 ft/198 m to the canyon floor on a 3 - 4 hour hike. The Swamp Canyon Loop also provides access to the 23 mi/37 km Under-the-Rim Trail. See nearby Swamp Canyon Loop Trailhead for more information.

Landscape Features

To the Southeast

Mud and Noon Canyon Buttes can be seen. Buttes are halfway along the erosional continuum between plateau and pinnacle. Plateaus are large regions of uplifted land. Mesas are isolated portions of plateaus that, although much smaller than plateaus, are still wider than they are tall. As mesas erode they give birth to buttes, which are square shaped, being approximately the same width as they are tall. As buttes erode still further they spawn spires of rocks.
At Bryce, our spires, known as hoodoos, are of a very special variety. The classic way a hoodoo forms begins with a narrow fin of rock that eventually develops holes or windows through the forces of frost wedging. As the windows grow they become arches. Eventually arches become too large to support their roofs. The inevitable collapse of a window leaves behind two broken legs of the arch. At Bryce we call broken arches hoodoos.
audioDescription: Swamp Canyon is a small overlook that provides a narrow view, surrounded on both sides by rock outcroppings of fins and hoodoos. The canyon here does not have a visible swamp but does have a small creek and a spring that fill the canyon bottom with vegetation like grasses and willows while pines and juniper trees climb the banks and cliffs.

images.altText: Grey sand and low shrubs with tall pink cliffs crumbling into forest below
images.title: Swamp Canyon Loop
images.caption: The Swamp Canyon Loop descends to the Under-the-Rim Trail and a sense of park backcountry

bodyText:
Swamp Canyon Loop

Difficulty: Moderate
Total Distance: 4.0 miles (6.4 km)
Ascent/Descent: 1,026 feet (313 m) / 1,034 feet (315 m)
Average time: 3-4 hours
The moderately strenuous 4.0 mi/6.4 km Swamp Canyon Loop begins here. The trail descends 647 ft/198 m to the canyon floor on a 3 - 4 hour hike. The loop is created by combining the Sheep Creek Connector Trail with 1.1 mi/1.8 km of the Under-the-Rim Trail and the Swamp Canyon Connector Trail. Both the Sheep Creek and Swamp Canyon connector trails provide access to the 23 mi/37 km Under-the-Rim Trail.

Under-the-Rim Trail

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 22.9 miles (37 km) from Rainbow Point to Bryce Point
Ascent: 5,884 feet (1,793 m)
Average time: 2-3 Days

This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m).
Experience the solitude of Bryce's forested backcountry on the Under-the-Rim Trail. Descending from the rim, this trail meanders through forests and meadows, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance. The Under the Rim Trail follows the base of the Paunsaugant Plateau and is largely forested. The hoodoos are part of the distant vistas to the west as you hike the valley floor. To preserve this experience, backcountry camping is permitted only in designated campsites. A backcountry permit must be obtained at the Visitor Center prior to any overnight trips. This trail is not as easily followed as developed trails within the Bryce Amphitheater.

Backcountry Hiking and Camping

The Under-the-Rim Trail is approximately 22.9 miles (36.9 km) from Bryce Point to Rainbow Point. Connecting trails offer access from the park's Scenic Drive and intersect the Under-the-Rim Trail at Swamp Canyon, and Whiteman Bench. Agua Canyon Connector Trail **is closed** until further notice due to storm damage.

The Riggs Spring Loop is an 8.6 mile (13.9 km) hike beginning and ending at the Rainbow and Yovimpa Point parking lot at the south end of the Scenic Drive. Either the Yovimpa or Rainbow Point trailhead may be used to access this loop.

A backcountry hiking map with mileage is available at the Visitor Center. More information

Permits Required

A Backcountry Permit is required for all overnight stays in the backcountry. Permits may be purchased at the Visitor Center from 9 am - 12:30 pm and 1:30 pm to 6 pm. Backcountry campsites are limited to 6 people per regular site, and 15 people per group site.

No Fires Permitted

Though gas-powered cooking stoves are allowed, no open fires are allowed anywhere in the park outside of North and Sunset Campground's established fire rings.

Bears and Other Wildlife

Bryce Canyon is home to many animals including mountain lions, coyotes and black bears. Squirrels, snakes and other small animals may also be present near your campsite.
Due to the presence of black bears within Bryce Canyon National Park, the use of bear-resistant food canisters on overnight backcountry hikes is highly recommended. Bear-resistant canisters are available for loan, free of charge, at the Visitor Center.

Transportation

No park-provided transportation is provided south of Bryce Point. You can arrange a private shuttle using approved providers listed on our Commercial Tours and Services page.
audioDescription: Swamp canyon trailhead is a narrow gravel path with low growing leathery leaves of the shrub green-leaf manzanita lining both sides of the trail. Two connecting trails are here to the Under-the-Rim trail and several backcountry camping sites. A trailhead panel with a map describes camping experiences and provides safety messages. Title reads: Swamp Canyon Trailhead A photo shows dense green forest in the foreground and a landform of red rock with vertical cliffs and a flat top in the distance, caption reads: Swamp Canyon Butte A detailed map of the park runs along the left side of the panel and illustrates all overlooks, shuttle stops, picnic areas, and camping and hiking opportunities. A You are Here arrow points to Swamp Canyon, north of Whiteman Bench and south of Inspiration Point. Panel content describes backcountry rules and campsites in the vicinity. Text reads: Bryce Canyon's Backcountry Bryce Canyon is best known for its hoodoos-bizarre pinnacles of rock left standing by the forces of erosion. Hoodoos are best experienced from the park's day hiking trails. By contrast, our backcountry trails offer forests, meadows, some interesting geologic features, lots of solitude, but few hoodoos. There are four backcountry campsites in the area of Swamp Canyon A color photograph for each of the four campgrounds shows a clearing in a forested area to set up camp. Right Fork Swamp Canyon Right fork swamped Canyon is .9 miles from the trailhead. caption reads nestled among tall Pines, Oak brush and mountain mahogany, there are nice views of cliffs and swamped Canyon Butte nearby. There is no water at the site but an unreliable source lies about .5 miles up the swamp Canyon connector just to the South of the trail. Swamp Canyon is 2.5 miles from the trailhead. There is no water at this site. Caption reads: This site is situated among junipers, furs and a few large pine trees there is no water anywhere near this site arguably, the best view in the back country is only .1 miles North of this site of breathtaking overlook of mud Canyon Sheep Creek Sheep Creek is 2.6 miles from the trailhead. There is water at this site. this campsite is shaded by Pines junipers and Oak brush. Sheep Creek can be heard flowing just to the S the tops of the pink cliffs are visible above the trees this site is more secluded than other Backcountry sites as it sits off the under the rim trail on a dead and spur. Yellow Creek Yellow Creek campsite is 6.2 miles from the trailhead. This site is shaded by Ponderosa Pines, but has an open area just to the west where Yellow Creek provides a reliable water source. There are good views of the pink cliffs of the Claron Formation and the Yellow Cliffs of the Straight Cliffs Formation.

title: The Legend People wayside
listingDescription: A panel along the overlook reads: The Legend People. Before there were any Indians, the legend people, To-when-an-Ung-wa, lived in that place…

images.altText: A panel describing Southern Paiute beliefs about the Bryce Canyon Landscape
images.title: The Legend People
images.caption: "The Legend People" wayside

bodyText:
A panel along the overlook reads: The Legend People.
Before there were any Indians, the legend people, To-when-an-Ung-wa, lived in that place… 

A sweeping image of the Bryce canyon landscape spans the top of the panel. Orange Hoodoos and plateaus are snow-covered for miles.

A close-up photograph of a coyote is superimposed in the foreground. With a caption that reads: Coyote God Sinawava- The “Trickster”
Text continues:
The Paiutes inhabited this region for hundreds of years before the arrival of European Americans. A sacred oral tradition of the Paiute Indians states that the hoodoos are ancient legend people turned into stone by coyote as a punishment for bad deeds. It is the custom of the Paiutes to tell these stories only during the winter season. Spring summer and fall are for hunting gathering and storing food it is out of respect for this custom that the authentic story is not repeated here. 

Four black and white photographs of the Paiutes taken by John Wesley Powel during the second Powell expedition in 1873 run along the bottom of the panel- caption reads:
In some photos, John Wesley Powell and his photographer John Cahill dressed Paiute Indians in costumes approximating Plains Indians attire to meet Eastern's expectations of the iconic Indian. The images chosen here attempt to depict their true dress. 

The first: two Paiute women standing in a landscape of desert shrubs with foothills in the background, each in a long deerskin dress, woven basket hats on their heads, large, round baskets strapped on their backs, both women hold large, flat, plate-like baskets in their hands.

Next image
Two young Paiute children with shoulder length black hair sit in the sand and brush. Each wearing a fringed deerskin dress. One holds an animal fur.  

The third image: two Paiute elders stand in discussion while a young child sits at their feet. The men wear a rectangular piece of tanned deerskin, or breechcloth between the legs so that the flaps fall in front and behind, each has a basket hat on their head tied around the chin. One man holds a long bow.

The last photo shows four Paiute men in discussion as they sit on the sandy ground near a cluster of trees. They are bare chested and wear buckskin leggings. Three men wear small basket hats, while one wears a cluster of feathers on his head.

title: Tower Bridge Hike the Hoodoos wayside
listingDescription: Hike the Hoodoos Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

images.altText: Wayside describing Hike the Hoodoos program, how to hike and claim your reward
images.title: Hike the Hoodoos Tower Bridge wayside
images.caption: "Hike the Hoodoos" wayside

bodyText:
I Hiked the Hoodoos

Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

1. Hike a minimum of 3 mi / 4.8 km, or find at least 3 benchmarks and complete steps 2 through 4 below.

2. Each individual must have either a pencil rubbing of the benchmark (see Jr. Ranger Book) or a"selfie"with the benchmark.

3. Only special "I Hiked the Hoodoos" benchmarks qualify for the reward.

4. Rewards are available at the Visitor Center!

See your park newspaper or Junior Ranger book for more information. Benchmarks are located on Mossy Cave, Rim Trail, Tower Bridge, Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, Peekaboo Loop, Sheep Creek, and the Bristlecone Loop trails.
audioDescription: Hike the Hoodoos Tower Bridge 386 words An exhibit panel titled: Hike the Hoodoos, Tower Bridge, promotes the parks Hike the Hoodoos challenge. There are nine "Hike the Hoodoos" benchmarks located along eight different hiking trails in the park. Each exhibit has a large round coin-like metal, medallion called a benchmark inserted into the panel. The right side of the panel illustrates a natural feature found at the location along with two photographs of the rocky landscape. The first is of a large butte formation called the sinking ship, a massive rock tilted higher on one end as if the back of the ship is sinking down, and the other of the Tower Bridge formation, a narrow horizontal ledge or bridge of resistant limestone held between two pillars of red limey mudstone. Text reads: In Bryce Canyon you can read earth’s history in layers of stone. Near sinking ship, slabs of earth’s crust are grinding past each other along the Paunsaugunt fault, raising the distant plateau known as Table Cliff. Hiking to Tower Bridge you can see how softer limestone spires have eroded leaving harder dolomitic limestone between them writing yet another chapter in this place is journey through time. The left side of each panel provides a trail map with current location, the benchmark and a description of the hoodoo challenge: This map shows our location on the Fairyland Loop Trail between Sunrise point and Fairyland point Text reads: Walk 1.5 miles down this trail to find the Tower bridge benchmark (metal disk below). Look for the benchmark on a sign at the trail junction. This is part of the “I hiked the hoodoos” challenge -- a way to stay healthy and have fun in your National Park. To meet the challenge: either find 3 benchmarks, or hike 3 miles on trails that have benchmarks see map and park newspaper or junior Ranger booklet bring rubbings of the benchmarks or photos of yourself with them to the visitor center to receive a small reward. The coin-shaped metal benchmark is mounted to the panel. Words have been etched into the metal: Bryce Canyon National Park Tower Bridge I hiked the hoodoos elevation 7251 feet above sea level. Text continues: This project was made possible in part by a grant from the National Park foundation through the generous support of the Coca Cola foundation.

title: Tower Bridge and Fairyland Loop Trailheads
listingDescription: Similar in difficulty to the Queen's / Navajo Combination loop, but far less travelled, the Tower Bridge trail provides excellent views of Boat Mesa, Sinking Ship, and other distant features within and outside the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park.

images.altText: A winding white sediment path winds past pine trees and a landscape of redrock cliffs and spires.
images.title: Tower Bridge Trail Bristlecones
images.caption: The Tower Bridge Trail descends along Boat Mesa and passes by groves of bristlecone pines.

bodyText:
Tower Bridge Trail

Difficulty: Moderate
Total Distance: 3.0 miles (4.8 km)
Elevation change: 802 feet (245 m)
Average time: 2-3 hours
Similar in difficulty to the Queen's / Navajo Combination loop, but far less travelled, the Tower Bridge trail provides excellent views of Boat Mesa, Sinking Ship, and other distant features within and outside the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park. The trail begins 0.25 miles (0.4 km) north of Sunrise Point along the Rim Trail and is part of the larger 8 mile (12.9 km) Fairyland Loop. It descends steadily 1.5 miles (2.4 miles) into Campbell Canyon, reaching a 200 yard spur trail that leads to the Tower Bridge hoodoo. Hikers should then turn around and ascend back to the rim to complete the hike. Those looking for a strenuous hike can continue on along the Fairyland Loop.
More about the trail

Fairyland Loop Trail

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 8.0 miles (12.9 km)
Elevation change: 1,716 feet (523 m)
Average time: 4-5 hours
Along the the Peekaboo Loop, the Fairyland Loop provides some of the best strenuous hiking in the park. It can be begun from either the Tower Bridge Trailhead or further notice at Fairyland Point (not accessible by vehicle in winter months). Spending 2.5 miles (4 km) along quiet ponderosa forests on the Rim Trail and the rest below surrounded by hoodoos within Fairyland and Campbell Canyons, it provides an excellent experience of the diversity above and below the rim. The trail can be hiked either clockwise or counter-clockwise, though many prefer the latter for the opportunity to descend rather than climb the Tower Bridge Trail section.
Generally the trail traces a large circle centered on Boat Mesa, the large flat-topped feature capped with the Conglomerate at Boat Mesa. This rock layer is one of the park's youngest, from a time after the freshwater lakes that would deposit the vibrant Claron Formation that forms the park's hoodoos had drained away, leaving large braided rivers that drained mountains to the north. 
More about the trail

Nature

Bristlecone Pines

Though Bryce Canyon is well known for its geology, the park also contains a fantastic diversity of trees. Among the most impressive of these is the Great Basin bristlecone pine (Pinus longaeva). These trees are known for thriving where few other plants can, and for far longer too. Look for bristlecone pines on exposures of dolomitic limestone. These areas of white to grey stone are found in the park's hoodoo-forming Claron formation as low as the Queen's Garden and Fairyland Loop trails. Dolomitic limestone is high in calcium and magnesium, and low in phosphorus. This chemistry is difficult for other plants to tolerate, giving the bristlecone pine plenty of room to grow as slowly as it likes. You'll also typically find higher-elevation bristlecones growing at the edges of cliffs, where competition is even further reduced. Free to take its time, bristlecones pines can grow as slowly as an inch (2.5 cm) per century if conditions are challenging. This gives these trees incredibly dense heartwood, which is capable of providing structural support to the tree long after a section of limb or trunk has lost its life-protecting bark. The oldest tree at Bryce Canyon was estimated to be 1,600 years old, though trees across its range into Nevada and California have been dated at over 5,000 years old, giving Pinus longaeva the honor of being the longest living non-clonal species on Earth.
You can identify a Bristlecone pine by its densely bundled needles of five (making it a white pine). Unlike many other pines that shed their needles every few years, bristlecone pines can retain needles for up to forty years. Their 1.5 in (1.2 cm) long needles remain vibrant and green for typically a full 12 inches (30 cm) along the branch. This appearance is often compared to that of a bottlebrush or pipe cleaner.
Like the limber pine (another white pine found at Bryce Canyon) seeds of the bristlecone pine may be harvested and dispersed to unlikely places by Clark's nutcrackers (Nucifraga columbiana). The seeds of their bristle-tipped cones are often among the first to colonize recently burnt areas.
Note that bristlecone pines share dolomitic limestones with some of the park's most delicate plants. Stay on the trail and help us to protect them.

I Hiked the Hoodoos

Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

1. Hike a minimum of 3 mi / 4.8 km, or find at least 3 benchmarks and complete steps 2 through 4 below.

2. Each individual must have either a pencil rubbing of the benchmark (see Jr. Ranger Book) or a"selfie"with the benchmark.

3. Only special "I Hiked the Hoodoos" benchmarks qualify for the reward.

4. Rewards are available at the Visitor Center!

See your park newspaper or Junior Ranger book for more information. Benchmarks are located on Mossy Cave, Rim Trail, Tower Bridge, Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, Peekaboo Loop, Sheep Creek, and the Bristlecone Loop trails.
audioDescription: A steeply descending trail turns off from the Rim Trail here alongside wooden retaining logs. A wayside for the Hike the Hoodoos program is placed beside the beginning of this trail. Native vegetation including pine trees and manzanita cover the slopes in all directions, with red rock spires--hoodoos--visible in the distance. A large pink and forested plateau is seen along the horizon.

title: Transportation Challenges wayside
listingDescription: In 1947 Bryce Canyon welcomed 163,000 visitors, most travelling by personal automobile. In 2018 the number of visitors exceeded 2.6 million. Park staff is continually developing creative solutions to address increasing visitation and protect this unique landscape for future generations, while making it available for all to safely experience and enjoy.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit interpreting the historic use of transportation in and to the park.
images.title: Transportation Challenges wayside
images.caption: To address transportation challenges, the park began offering a free shuttle service in 2000.

bodyText:
In 1947 Bryce Canyon welcomed 163,000 visitors, most travelling by personal automobile. In 2018 the number of visitors exceeded 2.6 million. Park staff is continually developing creative solutions to address increasing visitation and protect this unique landscape for future generations, while making it available for all to safely experience and enjoy.
To address these challenges, the park began offering a free shuttle service in 2000. Sixteen years later, the Shared Use Path offered a new option for cyclists, pedestrians, and even cross-country skiers. Debates continue around the need for new parking lots, roads, trails, and the impact these would have on the natural environment. How do you think the park should adapt to its popularity? How might people visit Bryce Canyon in the future?
audioDescription: The next panel titled: Transportation Challenges, reflects on the past and future of transportation in parks. A black and white photograph taken in 1930 shows two young men installing a wooden directional sign along the road that reads: Bryce Canyon five miles. Four inset photographs along the right side of the panel illustrate modes of transportation from motor cars on unpaved roads in 1925 to the early tour buses of 1935, then shuttle buses beginning in 2000 to riding bicycles along the shared use path today. Text continues: In 1947 Bryce Canyon welcomed 163,000 visitors, most travelling by personal automobile. In 2018 the number of visitors exceeded 2.6 million. Park staff is continually developing creative solutions to address increasing visitation and protect this unique landscape for future generations, while making it available for all to safely experience and enjoy. To address these challenges, the park began offering a free shuttle service in 2000. Sixteen years later, the Shared Use Path offered a new option for cyclists, pedestrians, and even cross-country skiers. Debates continue around the need for new parking lots, roads, trails, and the impact these would have on the natural environment. How do you think the park should adapt to its popularity? How might people visit Bryce Canyon in the future?

title: Tropic Ditch wayside
listingDescription: By 1874 members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints had begun to settle in the Paria Valley east of Bryce Canyon. Arid conditions gave rise to a plan to divert water 10 miles (16 km) from the East Fork of the Sevier River to the cliffs of Bryce Canyon and down into the valley. Approximately 40 men, digging with hand tools, began work in 1889. On May 23, 1892 their work was completed, and water from the plateau flowed down through Water Canyon.

images.altText: A wayside exhibit explaining the history of the Tropic Ditch
images.title: Tropic Ditch wayside
images.caption: The Tropic Ditch wayside

bodyText: By 1874 members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints had begun to settle in the Paria Valley east of Bryce Canyon. Arid conditions gave rise to a plan to divert water 10 miles (16 km) from the East Fork of the Sevier River to the cliffs of Bryce Canyon and down into the valley. Approximately 40 men, digging with hand tools, began work in 1889. On May 23, 1892 their work was completed, and water from the plateau flowed down through Water Canyon. The canal would become known as the Tropic Ditch, taking its name from the new town whose future this precious water secured.
audioDescription: Bringing Water to the Desert This panel illustrates how water was brought to the desert by a man-made irrigation ditch now called Tropic Ditch. Below is the streambed and above, hoodoos and fins of yellow and orange. The area is rich with plant life, pine, juniper, and low growing leathery leaved shrubs. An illustration across the top of the panel highlights five men in overalls with pickaxes, digging the shallow ditch by hand. Caption reads: Work leaders used natural water courses where possible to reduce the amount of digging. A dotted line on a topographic map represents the ten mile path of the ditch across the landscape, beginning from where the water was converted at the East Fork of the Sevier River to our location here at Water Canyon; a normally dry wash where irrigation water now typically flows from April to October and creates the waterfall nearby and shown as a photograph on the panel is part of the ditch that carries water to the town of Tropic. Text explains further: By 1874 members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints had begun to settle in the Paria Valley east of Bryce Canyon. Arid conditions gave rise to a plan to divert water 10 miles (16 km) from the East Fork of the Sevier River to the cliffs of Bryce Canyon and down into the valley. Approximately 40 men, digging with hand tools, began work in 1889. On May 23, 1892 their work was completed, and water from the plateau flowed down through Water Canyon. The canal would become known as the Tropic Ditch, taking its name from the new town whose future this precious water secured.

title: Tropic Trail Trailhead
listingDescription: One of the least-travelled front-country trails in the park, the Tropic Trail provides a unique point of entry into the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park. While all other hikes in this area begin on the rim and descend into the amphitheater, the Tropic Trail begins in lower elevation forest and steadily climbs to its intersection with the Peekaboo Loop, Navajo Loop, and Queen's Garden Trails.

images.altText: Tree branches partially obscure distant orange limestone spires
images.title: Tropic Trail
images.caption: The Tropic Trail leads through a juniper and pine forest toward the heart of the Bryce Amphitheater.

bodyText:
Tropic Trail

Difficulty: Moderate
Total Distance: 1.7 miles (2.7 km)
Elevation change: 591 feet (180 m)
Average time: 1-2 hours

One of the least-travelled front-country trails in the park, the Tropic Trail provides a unique point of entry into the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park.
While all other hikes in this area begin on the rim and descend into the amphitheater, the Tropic Trail begins in lower elevation forest and steadily climbs to its intersection with the Peekaboo Loop, Navajo Loop, and Queen's Garden Trails. Keep in mind that it will be a steep climb to reach the rim along any of these trails (should that be your goal), but if you take your time the Tropic Trail provides you with a relatively gentle and quiet way to enter and leave this popular area of the park.
audioDescription: Trailhead located at wire-fenced boundary of the park among tall pines, deciduous trees, and low brush. Signs read United States Department of Interior Boundary Line National Park Service along with signs prohibiting dogs, horses, and motorized vehicles. To access the trail one steps up three metal stairs and down three metal stairs on a staircase that straddles the wire fence. A trailhead sign with a map and brief description of the trail stands 25 feet further along the trail.

title: Tropic Trail wayside
listingDescription: One of the few trails in the park that begins below the rim, the Tropic Trail connects to Navajo Loop, Queen’s Garden, Peekaboo Loop, and Rim trails. It follows Bryce Creek, which is dry much of the year. The incline is initially gradual and connects to other popular and more strenuous hikes. Total ascent to the Rim Trail is over 1,000 feet.

images.altText: Park orientation and Tropic Trail orientation waysides.
images.title: Tropic Trail and Park Orientation
images.caption: Park Orientation and Tropic Trail Orientation waysides.

bodyText: One of the few trails in the park that begins below the rim, the Tropic Trail connects to Navajo Loop, Queen’s Garden, Peekaboo Loop, and Rim trails. It follows Bryce Creek, which is dry much of the year. The incline is initially gradual and connects to other popular and more strenuous hikes. Total ascent to the Rim Trail is over 1,000 feet. Ponderosa forest flanks the trail and the beautifully-colored, layered cliffs and hoodoos are, at first, seen from a distance. As you hike into the base of the amphitheater, these otherworldly formations surround and tower above you.
audioDescription: Two upright panels are here near the parking lot; the first is the orientation to Bryce Canyon with full park map. The second provides details about our location here at the Tropic Trail trailhead. A map illustrates that we are at the easternmost park boundary and a graphic provides details about the trail: Length: 1.5 miles (2.4 km) one way to Peekaboo Loop junction Difficulty: Moderate Total Ascent: 505 feet (154 m). A photograph along the bottom of the panel shows a view looking up toward the rim where evergreens give way to rugged red cliffs. Two inset photographs demonstrate things to do near here: people on horseback ride along the Peekaboo trail while hikers move along the switchbacks on the Navajo loop trail. Text reads: One of the few trails in the park that begins below the rim, the Tropic Trail connects to Navajo Loop, Queen’s Garden, Peekaboo Loop, and Rim trails. It follows Bryce Creek, which is dry much of the year. The incline is initially gradual and connects to other popular and more strenuous hikes. Total ascent to the Rim Trail is over 1,000 feet. Ponderosa forest flanks the trail and the beautifully-colored, layered cliffs and hoodoos are, at first, seen from a distance. As you hike into the base of the amphitheater, these otherworldly formations surround and tower above you.

title: Under-the-Rim and Riggs' Spring Trailhead
listingDescription: The Under-the-Rim Trail is approximately 22.9 miles (36.9 km) from Bryce Point to Rainbow Point. Connecting trails offer access from the park's Scenic Drive and intersect the Under-the-Rim Trail at Swamp Canyon, and Whiteman Bench. Agua Canyon Connector Trail **is closed** until further notice due to storm damage.

images.altText: Two backpackers hike along red rock path with distant forest and cliffs
images.title: Hikers along Under-the-Rim Trail
images.caption: The Under-the-Rim Trail descends from Rainbow Point toward distant Bryce Point

bodyText:
Under-the-Rim Trail

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 22.9 miles (37 km)
Ascent: 5,884 feet (1,793 m)
Average time: 2-3 Days

This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m).
Experience the solitude of Bryce's forested backcountry on the Under-the-Rim Trail. Descending from the rim, this trail meanders through forests and meadows, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance. The Under the Rim Trail follows the base of the Paunsaugant Plateau and is largely forested. The hoodoos are part of the distant vistas to the west as you hike the valley floor. To preserve this experience, backcountry camping is permitted only in designated campsites. A backcountry permit must be obtained at the Visitor Center prior to any overnight trips. This trail is not as easily followed as developed trails within the Bryce Amphitheater.

Note: the Agua Connecting Trail is closed until further notice.

Camping (Permits Available at Visitor Center)

There are 8 campsites on the 22.9 mile (36.9 km) Under-the-Rim Trail.

Riggs Spring Loop

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 8.8 miles (14.2 km)
Ascent:  2,503 feet (763 m)
Average time: 4-6 Hours

This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m).
Descending from the rim, this 8.8 mile (14.2 km) trail meanders through forests and raised promontories, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance. Gain a new perspective of the Grand Staircase by descending to its next stair--the Cretaceous sandstones of the Grey Cliffs. To preserve this experience, backcountry camping is permitted only in designated campsites. A backcountry permit must be obtained at the Visitor Center prior to any overnight trips. This trail is not as easily followed as developed trails within the Bryce Amphitheater.

Camping (Permits Available at Visitor Center)

There are 4 campsites on the 8.8 mile (14.2 km) Riggs Spring Loop Trail, which also can be accessed from here. You must obtain a permit to use these sites.

Backcountry Hiking and Camping

The Under-the-Rim Trail is approximately 22.9 miles (36.9 km) from Bryce Point to Rainbow Point. Connecting trails offer access from the park's Scenic Drive and intersect the Under-the-Rim Trail at Swamp Canyon, and Whiteman Bench. Agua Canyon Connector Trail **is closed** until further notice due to storm damage.

The Riggs Spring Loop is an 8.6 mile (13.9 km) hike beginning and ending at the Rainbow and Yovimpa Point parking lot at the south end of the Scenic Drive. Either the Yovimpa or Rainbow Point trailhead may be used to access this loop.

A backcountry hiking map with mileage is available at the Visitor Center. More information

Permits Required

A Backcountry Permit is required for all overnight stays in the backcountry. Permits may be purchased at the Visitor Center from 9 am - 12:30 pm and 1:30 pm to 6 pm. Backcountry campsites are limited to 6 people per regular site, and 15 people per group site.

No Fires Permitted

Though gas-powered cooking stoves are allowed, no open fires are allowed anywhere in the park outside of North and Sunset Campground's established fire rings.

Bears and Other Wildlife

Bryce Canyon is home to many animals including mountain lions, coyotes and black bears. Squirrels, snakes and other small animals may also be present near your campsite.
Due to the presence of black bears within Bryce Canyon National Park, the use of bear-resistant food canisters on overnight backcountry hikes is highly recommended. Bear-resistant canisters are available for loan, free of charge, at the Visitor Center.

Transportation

No park-provided transportation is provided south of Bryce Point. You can arrange a private shuttle using approved providers listed on our Commercial Tours and Services page.
audioDescription:
Rainbow Point Trailhead
A color photograph shows a landscape of curving, jagged orange and red rock spires that run along the uppermost edge of the canyon rim. In the valley below, a dark green sea of pine trees. Caption reads: View from Rainbow Point

A detailed map of the park runs along the left side of the panel and illustrates overlooks, shuttle stops, picnic areas, and camping and hiking opportunities. A You are Here arrow points to Rainbow Point, near the southernmost end of the park.

Panel content describes backcountry rules, safety, trails and campsites in the vicinity.
Text reads:
Bryce Canyon is best known for its hoodoos-bizarre pinnacles of rock left
standing by the forces of erosion. Hoodoos are best experienced from the park's
day hiking trails. By contrast, our backcountry trails offer forests, meadows,
some interesting geologic features, lots of solitude, but few hoodoos.

There are four backcountry campsites in the Rainbow Point area: Iron Spring, Corral Hollow, Riggs Spring and Yovimpa Pass. A color photograph for each of the four campgrounds shows a clearing in a forested area to set up camp.

title: Visitor Center
listingDescription: The Bryce Canyon Visitor Center might be one of your first stops when visiting Bryce Canyon National Park. Here you can obtain driving and hiking directions beyond those available on this website, weather forecasts, a current schedule of Park Ranger guided programs, Junior Ranger booklets, and information on area services including lodging, dining and other attractions.

images.altText: A metal sign reading Bryce Canyon National Park stands in front of a large building with green roof
images.title: Visitor Center
images.caption: The Visitor Center might be your first stop when entering the park

bodyText:
Your purchases through the Bryce Canyon Association bookstore directly support this park.
Visit the Bryce Canyon Natural History Association Online 

The Bryce Canyon Visitor Center might be one of your first stops when visiting Bryce Canyon National Park. Here you can obtain driving and hiking directions beyond those available on this website, weather forecasts, a current schedule of Park Ranger guided programs, Junior Ranger booklets, and information on area services including lodging, dining and other attractions.

While at the Visitor Center you will want to see our new awarding winning film, "A Song of Seasons." The film plays on the hour and half hour throughout the day. Also take the time to explore our museum exhibits and our bookstore.

The Bryce Canyon Visitor Center is open every day. During the summer our hours are 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. with reduced hours of 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. in fall and spring and 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. during the winter. Learn more about operating hours.
audioDescription: Visitor Center 223 words The park entrance station and visitor center are near the north end of the park along the main road, within a large expanse of sagebrush meadow and directly surrounded by stands of ponderosa pine. The entrance station along the road has three one room small kiosk booths with windows on all four sides. Park entrance tickets and information are available upon entrance. The visitor center is a 3 story L shaped building on a concrete foundation. Its construction although newer, is similar to the rustic style of the other buildings within the park; a combination of studs-out wood appearance emphasizing the framing as a decorative pattern on the exterior of the building and large exterior stone pillars at each of the buildings corners. The sharply pitched gable roof is covered with green corrugated metal roofing. The outside walls are painted dark brown and contrast with the lighter colored stone facing. A low stone wall runs around the base of the building. There are nearby pedestrian trails, a shuttle bus stop and available parking in the front. At the entrance of the building there is an informational tactile touch table to illustrate the topography within the canyon landscape along with interpretive panels and orientation maps. The visitor center houses a museum with exhibits, a small theater, restrooms, water station, visitor information and a bookstore.

title: Wall of Windows Hike the Hoodoos
listingDescription: Hike the Hoodoos Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

images.altText: Wayside showing a wall of redrock limestone being shaped by ice also describes Hike the Hoodoos
images.title: Wall of Windows Hike the Hoodoos wayside
images.caption: Wall of Windows Hike the Hoodoos wayside (be sure to include yourself in your photo!)

bodyText:
I Hiked the Hoodoos

Hiking is great exercise and Bryce Canyon's "I Hiked the Hoodoos!" program is not just hiking, it's also a scavenger hunt with a special reward!

1. Hike a minimum of 3 mi / 4.8 km, or find at least 3 benchmarks and complete steps 2 through 4 below.

2. Each individual must have either a pencil rubbing of the benchmark (see Jr. Ranger Book) or a"selfie"with the benchmark.

3. Only special "I Hiked the Hoodoos" benchmarks qualify for the reward.

4. Rewards are available at the Visitor Center!

See your park newspaper or Junior Ranger book for more information. Benchmarks are located on Mossy Cave, Rim Trail, Tower Bridge, Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, Peekaboo Loop, Sheep Creek, and the Bristlecone Loop trails.
audioDescription: Wall of Windows 469 words "Wall of Windows Hike the Hoodoos" wayside panel is along the western side of the Peekaboo Loop facing north along a winding portion of the trail. Above is a natural feature known as the Wall of Windows: a fin of white limestone protruding from the rim of the Bryce Amphitheater where large arches or windows in the rock have been carved by ice, rain, gravity, and wind. Exhibit title: Hike the Hoodoos, Wall of Windows, promotes the parks Hike the Hoodoos challenge. There are nine "Hike the Hoodoos" benchmarks located along eight different hiking trails in the park. Each exhibit has a large round coin-like metal, medallion called a benchmark inserted into the panel. The right side of the exhibit panel illustrates with photographs, the three different rock formations found here, fins, pockets and windows. First, fins, long narrow rock walls, like a fish’s dorsal fin, each spine is a pillar of stone stacked tightly to the next in a row. Next, windows: a close-up photograph of rock fins that now have pockets or tunnels created by erosion that will eventually break through to create a hole or window through the rock. Last, Windows, a photograph of a rock formation with a window framing the blue sky through it, the pockets have eroded completely through to the other side, creating window through the rock. Text reads: Nature's recipe for a rock window at Bryce: begin with massive hunks of limestone, sandstone, and other rock originally laid down as Lake sediments 50 million years ago. Add Frost wedging and flowing water to erode the rock into tall fins. Using mildly acidic rain, create pockets in these fins. Erode the pockets until a hole appears. Repeat. Repeat. Repeat. The left side of each panel provides a trail map with current location, the benchmark and a description of the hoodoo challenge: This map shows our location in between Bryce point to the south and inspiration point to the north along the Peekaboo loop trail. Text reads: You have found the Peekaboo Loop benchmark (metal disk below) on the “I hiked the hoodoos” challenge -- a way to stay healthy and have fun in your National Park. To meet the challenge: either find 3 benchmarks, or hike 3 miles on trails that have benchmarks see map and park newspaper or junior Ranger booklet bring rubbings of the benchmarks or photos of yourself with them to the visitor center to receive a small reward. The coin-shaped metal benchmark is mounted to the panel. Words have been etched into the metal: Bryce Canyon National Park Peek a Boo I hiked the hoodoos elevation 7640 feet above sea level. Text continues: This project was made possible in part by a grant from the National Park foundation through the generous support of the Coca Cola foundation.

title: Watching for Wildlife Wayside
listingDescription: An illustration of 13 of the most frequently seen mammals and birds found within the park, all circled around a Ponderosa pine tree. Junior Ranger mascot Ranger Ringtail provides an important reminder: Help us protect the animals of Bryce Canyon. Some might beg for food, but remember they are wild. Do not feed or try to touch them.

images.altText: Illustration of 13 of the most frequently seen mammals and birds found within the park.
images.title: Watching for Wildlife Wayside
images.caption: Do not feed or try to touch wild animals, even if they're begging for food.

bodyText: An illustration of 13 of the most frequently seen mammals and birds found within the park, all circled around a Ponderosa pine tree. Junior Ranger mascot Ranger Ringtail provides an important reminder: Help us protect the animals of Bryce Canyon. Some might beg for food, but remember they are wild. Do not feed or try to touch them.
audioDescription: An illustration features 13 of the most frequently seen mammals and birds found within the park. All the animals are clustered artistically on and around the trunk of a Ponderosa pine tree while the Junior Ranger mascot Ranger Ringtail provides an important reminder: Help us protect the animals of Bryce Canyon. Some might beg for food, but remember they are wild. Do not feed or try to touch them. Text continues: Watching For Wildlife Ringtail Active at night, ringtails, also called ringtail cats, climb trees looking for insects, lizards, and other small meals. Bobcat The bobcat gets its name from its short “bob” tail. Sometimes seen during the day, this cat is most active at dawn and dusk. Its main prey are rabbits, like the desert cottontail. Pygmy nuthatch Usually seen in large family groups, these grey and white birds are the park’s smallest nuthatches. Listen for their squeak which sounds like a rubber ducky. Raven These large birds are found throughout the park. They are very playful fliers and are very smart. Their usual call is a low croak, but they also make sounds to imitate other birds. White-Breasted nuthatch The park’s largest nuthatch has a gray back, black striped head, and white face and belly. It can be seen moving head-first down the bark of trees looking for food. Coyote Coyotes can be seen hunting during the day. In areas with lots of people, they hunt at night. They eat small animals, insects, reptiles, birds, and grass. Near people they will eat trash and pet food. Golden-mantled ground squirrel These small rodents have a white eye ring, while chipmunks have stripes on their faces. They can be found in all areas of the park, often approaching people for food. Remember to never feed any wildlife! Steller’s jay These are bold and curious birds with a large black crest and blue feathers. Listen for their loud “shack-shack-shack” call in the trees. They are often seen swooping between trees or on the ground. Downy woodpecker The smallest woodpecker in North America, might be seen along a tree branch or trunk where it makes lots of noise drumming its small bill. The male has a red spot on his head. Mule deer Mule deer are one of the park’s most common mammals. They get their name from their big, mule-like ears. These deer can be seen throughout the day, but are usually in meadows in the morning and evening. Brown creeper These birds blend in very well with tree bark as they search for insects to eat. You might see them as they fly to land near the bottom of a tree and work their way up. Their calls are very high-pitched. Desert cottontail These small gray rabbits have white tails and are usually seen in hilly areas. They can be seen all day, but more often in the early morning or late afternoon. Their tracks are often spotted in the snow. Utah prairie dog The smallest of all prairie dogs. Usually seen near the mounded entrances of their underground homes. Listen for their chattering bark. They may be warning others about a nearby predator, maybe you!

quickFacts.value: Along the Shared-Use Path
quickFacts.name: Location

title: Water Canyon wayside

images.altText: A wayside exhibit explaining how water flowing here creates a unique oasis uncommon in the desert.
images.title: Water Canyon wayside
images.caption: Water Canyon wayside exhibit.

bodyText: Listen to the rushing stream. For many plants and animals it is the sound of life, yet it is also the sound of rapid change. In 1892, water for the town of Tropic was diverted into this once seasonal drainage, transforming Water Canyon into one of the fastest eroding areas of the park. Though nearby natural springs have long provided refuges for plants and animals, here erosion from the constant and rapid flow of water creates a demanding environment for new plants. Soil compacted by hikers creates additional challenges for life here. By staying on the trail, you help preserve the delicate and resilient beauty of this flora.
audioDescription: Water Canyon A panel along the trail just past the first bridge explains how water flowing here at Mossy Cave creates a unique oasis for plants in the desert to flourish. A photograph of yellow Rabbitbrush and purple aster growing alongside the stream covers the panel. Four other plants found here are featured: The yellowish green bog orchid one of the few flowers pollinated by mosquitos blooms from June through August, thrives in a wet habitats. Next the Narrowleaf cottonwood tree, shown here with its golden leaves of autumn, thrives in wetlands and arid habitats. Their seeds are surrounded by a soft white fluff which looks like cotton. Then the pink, five-petaled Nootka Rose, a spring bloomer, is native to the western United States. Wild rose hip fruit, used as food and medicine, is high in vitamin C. Last, willows with their silvery, green lance shaped leaves are found primarily on moist soil. Butterflies, ants, and bees feed on the leaves, bark, and flowers. Text continues: Listen to the rushing stream. For many plants and animals it is the sound of life, yet it is also the sound of rapid change. In 1892, water for the town of Tropic was diverted into this once seasonal drainage, transforming Water Canyon into one of the fastest eroding areas of the park. Though nearby natural springs have long provided refuges for plants and animals, here erosion from the constant and rapid flow of water creates a demanding environment for new plants. Soil compacted by hikers creates additional challenges for life here. By staying on the trail, you help preserve the delicate and resilient beauty of this flora.

title: What's In A Name? wayside
listingDescription: In 1875, a Scottish immigrant, Ebenezer Bryce, and his family joined other settlers in the valley to the east. To access timber, he built a road that ended in an amphitheater of pink cliffs. Others started calling it “Bryce’s Canyon.” Bryce and his family moved to Arizona in 1880, never anticipating his name would remain over a century later.

images.altText: Wayside exhibit explaining place names in Bryce Canyon.
images.title: What's In A Name? wayside
images.caption: Ebenezer Bryce (1830-1913) worked hard to make a living in this beautiful, challenging, landscape.

bodyText: In 1875, a Scottish immigrant, Ebenezer Bryce, and his family joined other settlers in the valley to the east. To access timber, he built a road that ended in an amphitheater of pink cliffs. Others started calling it “Bryce’s Canyon.” Bryce and his family moved to Arizona in 1880, never anticipating his name would remain over a century later.
audioDescription: A panoramic wintertime photograph of the majestic and rugged Bryce amphitheater fills the panel. Below, deep reddish orange hoodoos and evergreens are dusted in snow, low level clouds to the east, rolling hills in the far distance. Text Reads: What's in a Name? Southern Paiutes call this place Unka-koh-vah-wong-weents, which means “Red Face Standing”. Within these bowl-shaped areas—amphitheaters—stands the world’s greatest concentration of irregular rock spires, called “hoodoos”. The word is a mistranslation of the Paiute word “Oodoo”, which describes fear among faces and forms in the rocks. An inset sepia toned photograph taken in 1873 during the John Wesley Powell expedition down the Colorado River illustrates two Paiutes and their dome shaped shelters made of natural materials. Caption reads: The Southern Paiute’s sacred oral tradition says the hoodoos are ancient “Legend People” turned to stone by the trickster god, Coyote, as a punishment for bad deeds. Text Continues: In 1875, a Scottish immigrant, Ebenezer Bryce, and his family joined other settlers in the valley to the east. To access timber, he built a road that ended in an amphitheater of pink cliffs. Others started calling it “Bryce’s Canyon.” Bryce and his family moved to Arizona in 1880, never anticipating his name would remain over a century later. A black and white formal photo portrait of Ebenezer Bryce taken in 1875. He wears a black suit coat and vest with white shirt. His dark hair is short and combed, his long grey beard obscures his bowtie. Caption Reads Ebenezer Bryce (1830-1913) worked hard to make a living in this beautiful, yet challenging, landscape.

title: Whiteman Bench Picnic Area
listingDescription: Picnic tables are available for use at this pull-out surrounded by burned forest.

images.altText: Burned trees and a path among picnic tables and distant forest
images.title: Whiteman Bench Picnic Area
images.caption: 1 of 6 picnic areas along with North CG, the General Store, Sunset Point, Mile 5, and Rainbow Point.

bodyText:
Picnic tables are available for use at this pull-out surrounded by burned forest.

Bridge Fire

The Bridge Fire began on June 14th, 2009 at Bridge Hollow on the Dixie National Forest to the west. It was closely monitored for resource benefits in this fire-dependent ecosystem, including re-establishing aspen and ponderosa pine in an area dominated by shade-tolerant white fire. Due to the nature of mixed conifer forest, with dense trees low in the understory, the stand-replacing fire behavior you see was normal and expected.
Hot and dry conditions combined with strong winds contributed to very fast-moving fire behavior, and the the Bridge fire entered the park on July 14th. Ultimately around 3,500 acres (about 50% in the park and 50% on Forest Service land) would burn. The burned area stretches along Whiteman Bench between Swamp Canyon and Farview Point for about 1.5 miles, primarily to the west, and in some places reaches below the rim to the east. This was the largest natural wildfire in the park's history.
300 firefighters from Utah, Nevada, and Arkansas would cooperate to hold the fire along the main park road. Three helicopters were in use for aerial foam and water drops.
There were no injuries or property damage. On July 14th at 4:30 p.m. approximately 50 vehicles were led down from Rainbow Point and escorted out of the park on the Yovimpa Pass Road--a forest service road that bypassed the fire along the main road. Another 10 RVs and motorcycles unable to travel the forest service road were escorted down the main road when it was safe.
Today, the snags (dead, standing trees) provide important habitat for a variety of species, including woodpeckers, nuthatches, owls, and small mammals who will help to disperse the seeds that will regenerate this forest.
What regrowth can you see from where you stand?
audioDescription: Here along the main park road, two picnic tables sit at the end of a crushed stone path that briefly winds though a few ponderosa pines. The landscape was clearly burned not too long ago, with dead standing trees and many fallen ones among new shrub growth. Distant views are of a forested valley with pale orange and white rock exposures with some rock spires among the trees.

title: Whiteman Connecting Trail Trailhead
listingDescription: Experience the solitude of Bryce's forested backcountry on the Under the Rim Trail. Descending from the rim, this 22.9 mile (37 km) trail meanders through forests and meadows, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance.

images.altText: A forested slope foreground with red rock cliffs and plateaus beyond
images.title: Whiteman Connecting Trail
images.caption: The Whiteman Connecting Trail provides distant views of the Paria Valley along its descent

bodyText:
Whiteman Connecting Trail

Difficulty: Moderate
Total Distance: 1.0 miles (1.6 km)
Ascent/Descent: 16 feet (4.9 m) / 490 feet (149 m)
Average time: 1-2 hours

This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m).
This trail descends 1.0 mile (1.6 km) to its junction with the Under-the-Rim Trail.

Under-the-Rim Trail

Difficulty: Strenuous
Total Distance: 22.9 miles (37 km) from Rainbow Point to Bryce Point
Ascent: 5,884 feet (1,793 m)
Average time: 2-3 Days

This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m).
Experience the solitude of Bryce's forested backcountry on the Under-the-Rim Trail. Descending from the rim, this trail meanders through forests and meadows, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance. The Under the Rim Trail follows the base of the Paunsaugant Plateau and is largely forested. The hoodoos are part of the distant vistas to the west as you hike the valley floor. To preserve this experience, backcountry camping is permitted only in designated campsites. A backcountry permit must be obtained at the Visitor Center prior to any overnight trips. This trail is not as easily followed as developed trails within the Bryce Amphitheater.

Backcountry Hiking and Camping

The Under-the-Rim Trail is approximately 22.9 miles (36.9 km) from Bryce Point to Rainbow Point. Connecting trails offer access from the park's Scenic Drive and intersect the Under-the-Rim Trail at Swamp Canyon, and Whiteman Bench. Agua Canyon Connector Trail **is closed** until further notice due to storm damage.

The Riggs Spring Loop is an 8.6 mile (13.9 km) hike beginning and ending at the Rainbow and Yovimpa Point parking lot at the south end of the Scenic Drive. Either the Yovimpa or Rainbow Point trailhead may be used to access this loop.

A backcountry hiking map with mileage is available at the Visitor Center. More information

Permits Required

A Backcountry Permit is required for all overnight stays in the backcountry. Permits may be purchased at the Visitor Center from 9 am - 12:30 pm and 1:30 pm to 6 pm. Backcountry campsites are limited to 6 people per regular site, and 15 people per group site.

No Fires Permitted

Though gas-powered cooking stoves are allowed, no open fires are allowed anywhere in the park outside of North and Sunset Campground's established fire rings.

Bears and Other Wildlife

Bryce Canyon is home to many animals including mountain lions, coyotes and black bears. Squirrels, snakes and other small animals may also be present near your campsite.
Due to the presence of black bears within Bryce Canyon National Park, the use of bear-resistant food canisters on overnight backcountry hikes is highly recommended. Bear-resistant canisters are available for loan, free of charge, at the Visitor Center.

Transportation

No park-provided transportation is provided south of Bryce Point. You can arrange a private shuttle using approved providers listed on our Commercial Tours and Services page.

A You are Here arrow points to Whiteman Bench, very near the middle of the park. Panel content describes backcountry rules and campsites in the vicinity. Text continues: Bryce Canyon's Backcountry Bryce Canyon is best known for its hoodoos-bizarre pinnacles of rock left standing by the forces of erosion. Hoodoos are best experienced from the park's day hiking trails. By contrast, our backcountry trails offer forests, meadows, some interesting geologic features, lots of solitude, but few hoodoos. title: Yovimpa Point
listingDescription: Along with Rainbow Point, Yovimpa Point is one of the highest viewpoints in the park. Tectonic uplift has lifted this entire scene from sea-level over the course of the last 20 million years to later be dissected by tributaries of the Colorado River.

images.altText: A red and white limestone rock cliff lit with sunlight above a vast forested landscape.
images.title: Yovimpa Point
images.caption: Yovimpa Point looks south from one of the highest viewpoints in the park.

bodyText:
Along with Rainbow Point, Yovimpa Point is one of the highest viewpoints in the park. Tectonic uplift has lifted this entire scene from sea-level over the course of the last 20 million years to later be dissected by tributaries of the Colorado River. Tilting that occurred during uplift has situated the southern end of the park approximately 1,000 ft (304 m) higher than its northern end. Here you can gaze from the southern tip of the Paunsaugunt plateau and overlook the colorful cliffs of the Grand Staircase.

Trails

Access to both the Riggs Spring Loop and Bristlecone Loop can be found on the sidewalk leading from the parking lot to Yovimpa Point.

Landscape Features

To the South

One of the grandest, and longest views in the park, extending over 100 miles (161 km) across the tops of the colorful "steps", or cliffs, of the Grand Staircase. Below you and to either side are beautiful exposures of Bryce Canyon's Pink Cliffs, soft limey mudstones colored by iron-oxide (rust) being shaped into beautiful forms by rain and the power frost-wedging ice. Below them, obscured in part by forest, are the soft marine shales and silts of the Grey Cliffs. Beyond these are deep canyons carved into the sandstones of the White Cliffs, which are also beautifully exposed at Zion National Park further west. Note the feature known as "Molly's Nipple", which appears like a conical mountain among the White Cliffs. This is not a dormant volcano, but instead an area capped with a more erosion-resistant form of sandstone. The bottom two steps--the Vermillion Cliffs as well as the Chocolate Cliffs are dificult to discern from this distance. The horizon is the Kaibab Upwarp, which forms the northern rim of Grand Canyon. The five cliffs of the Grand Staircase that extend from this point to the Kaibab Upwarp contain one of the world's most complete sedimentary records of the last 300 million years of life and environment on the planet.

To the Southeast

Navajo Mountain looms on the distant horizon over 80 miles away near Page, Arizona. Called a laccolith, Navajo Mountain can be thought of as a volcano that never quite happened. As the Colorado Plateau was uplifted by tectonic forces, a plume of molten rock moved upward from deep inside the Earth causing a swelling much like a large blister. Unlike a volcano, Navajo Mountain never blew its top and so the plume cooled slowly, creating the hard core of the mountain that still exists today.
audioDescription: A path runs adjacent to the plateaus edge and is enclosed with a horizontal log railing. This overlook offers a view to the south and includes a large portion of the sequence of rock layers called the Grand Staircase: step-like cliffs, each step or rock layer is made from hard, colorful sedimentary rocks beginning at the bottom with chocolate colored Mudstone, Vermilion mudstone and sandstone, White sandstone, Grey Shales and Pink Limestones. The canyon stretches on for miles and below the valleys are covered in a dense green carpet of forest with only the plateau edges and steep cliffs of pink and orange rock void of any vegetation.

quickFacts.name: Location

listingDescription: Most visitors expect clean air and clear views in parks. Bryce Canyon National Park (NP), Utah, is home to the largest concentration of hoodoos—totem-shaped rock spires resistant to erosion—in the world. The park enjoys relatively good air quality given its remote location on the Colorado Plateau. However, upwind urban and industrial sources, including large power plants and mines, can harm the park’s natural and scenic resources such as vegetation, surface waters, and visibi

images.altText: A distant view of a rounded mountain beyond rocky cliffs and pine trees
images.title: Yovimpa Air Quality Camera
images.caption: The Yovimpa Air Quality camera monitors toward Navajo Mountain.

bodyText:
View the Webcam

Please note this station is located in an area not open to the public.

Most visitors expect clean air and clear views in parks. Bryce Canyon National Park (NP), Utah, is home to the largest concentration of hoodoos—totem-shaped rock spires resistant to erosion—in the world. The park enjoys relatively good air quality given its remote location on the Colorado Plateau. However, upwind urban and industrial sources, including large power plants and mines, can harm the park’s natural and scenic resources such as vegetation, surface waters, and visibility.

Learn more about park air quality

bodyText:
From here hikers descend on the 8.6-mile (13.8 km) Riggs Spring Loop Trail. Those looking to hike the rugged 22.9-mile (36.9 km) Under-the-Rim Trail, which travels north to Bryce Point, should begin near Rainbow Point. Day hikers might enjoy the nearby Bristlecone Loop or views of distant mesas and steep plateau cliffs along the strenuous Riggs Spring Loop.

This trailhead connects to the Riggs Spring Loop, 8.6 miles (13.8 km); Bristlecone Loop, 1 mile (1.6 km); and the Under-the-Rim Trail, 22.6 miles (36.4 km).
audioDescription: One orientation panel to the south of the Rainbow Point parking lot provides trail access information for hiking the backcountry trails at Yovimpa Point. A map illustrates the location of the trails and a graphic provides details about the trail: Length: Bristlecone: 1 mile (1.6 km); Riggs Spring: 8.6 miles (13.8 km); Under-the-Rim: 22.9 miles (36.9 km) Difficulty: Bristlecone: Easy; Riggs Spring: Strenuous; Under-the-Rim: Strenuous Total Ascent: Bristlecone: 200 feet (61 m); Riggs Spring: 2,200 feet (671 m); Under-the-Rim: 5,500 feet (1,676 m) A photograph along the bottom of the panel shows two hikers heading into the canyon along the narrow trail. Steep terra cotta-colored embankments surround them. Text Continues: From here hikers descend on the 8.6-mile (13.8 km) Riggs Spring Loop Trail. Those looking to hike the rugged 22.9-mile (36.9 km) Under-the-Rim Trail, which travels north to Bryce Point, should begin near Rainbow Point. Day hikers might enjoy the nearby Bristlecone Loop or views of distant mesas and steep plateau cliffs along the strenuous Riggs Spring Loop. This trailhead connects to the Riggs Spring Loop, 8.6 miles (13.8 km); Bristlecone Loop, 1 mile (1.6 km); and the Under-the-Rim Trail, 22.6 miles (36.4 km). The Riggs Spring Loop Trail is a strenuous backcountry trail that plunges into the canyons below Yovimpa Point, completing a 8.6-mile (13.8 km) loop between Rainbow and Yovimpa points.
